NEW-YORK: PRINTED BY G. F. HOPKINS, FOR WILLIAM DUNLAP. AND SOLD AT THE OFFICE OF THE PRINTER, NO. 84 MAIDEN-LANE; T. AND J. SWORDS, NO. 99 PEARL-STREET; CAINE AND TENEYCK, NO. 148 PEARL-STREET; JOHN BLACK, NO. 5 CEDAR-STREET; ALEX. SOMERVILLE, NO. 114 MAIDEN-LANE; AND MOST OTHER BOOKSELLERS IN THE U. STATES. 1800.

p.hi: IT was the intention of the Subscriber, to have prefaced the first number of the GERMAN THEATRE, by some remarks relative to the undertaking; but, having accidentally met with the Life of the Author, who, from his unparalleled popularity, will probably occupy the largest portion of the work, he has concluded, that such an introduction as the "Literary Life of A. Von Kotzebue," would be much more acceptable to the public than the matter originally intended.

div.head: THE LIFE OF AUGUSTUS VON KOTZEBUE. WRITTEN BY HIMSELF. MY LITERARY LIFE.
div.p: AS an author, I have experienced both good and bad success, both in a high degree, both frequently unmerited. I flatter myself that it may be useful to young men desirous of entering upon the slippery career of literature, to read the history of a man, who has not reached the goal indeed—for how few ever do reach it!—but who has so far advanced before them in the progress towards it; one who, without ceremony, joins their circle, and relates without disguise when he fell, when he erred, and when he was deceived; where he enjoyed the assistance of the Nine, and where he mistook the ravings of a Bacchante for the inspiration of the Muse.

Come hither, then, ye inexperienced youths, who have, for the first time, dipped the tip of your tongue in the honey of Parnassus, and think it desirable because it is sweet; sit down and listen to me. You see I am in the vein; my soul is unconstrained, and my lips are opened to confess with candour when I have been deluded by vanity, and when my mind has been warmed with the feelings of the true and the beautiful.

Rise then! rise before me, ye fairy phantoms of my happy childhood! In remembrance you now scarce form a part of the being I now am! Rise and hover round me, ye gentle shades!—Gracious Providence! suffer once more those delightful hours to rise out of the ocean of the past, like a dim mist before my fancy!

Seize then the fleeting shades as they pass!—Seest thou there that boy who hangs with rapt attention on his mother's tongue, as she reads to him and his sister some winter evening
the interesting tale?—That boy was yourself!—Seest thou again how he makes the chair his table, and the footstool his chair? See how he devours the romance, while ball and playthings lie neglected in the corner!—That boy was yourself!

My honored mother—Heaven be praised she still lives, she hears my grateful acknowledgments—My good mother, when but a very young widow, denied herself many of the pleasures and enjoyments of life, to devote herself entirely, to the education of her children. She possessed taste, reading, sensibility, and a rich portion of patient maternal affection. With these qualities, her efforts could not be wholly unsuccessful. She provided preceptors of different kinds, but to her own discernment and taste I owe more than to the tutors to whose care my instruction was confided.

In the evening I used to read to her in the parlour. The first book that made a lively impression on me was a Collection of Tales selected from all languages, then in great repute; the next was Don Quixote; Robinson Crusoe then engrossed my fancy, and I wished myself the possessor of some desert island.

Even in my sixth year I began to compose rude essays in verse; not long after I made my first dramatic effort. I made a comedy, which was just the length of an octavo page. I was sensible, indeed, that it ought to be much longer, in order to resemble a comedy; but who was to teach me the art of spinning out the thread, and expanding my materials?

I now come to that incident of my life, which, in its consequences, produced the greatest influence on my character, and from my tenderest childhood irrevocably destined me to be a dramatic writer. The late Abt, the player, came with his strolling company to Weimar. Since I possessed any power of thought, there had been no players in Weimar, and my curiosity was unbounded. Musaeus, the amiable and excellent Musaeus, who was attached to me from a child, offered to take me to the theatre.

I went with a kind of reverential awe; my expectation was wound up to the highest pitch. The piece was Klopstock's Death of Adam. Musaeus placed me before him on a bench, that I might see over the heads of the spectators. The curtain drew up. I was all ear, all eye. Not a word, not a movement escaped me. Never had I before experienced such powerful impressions. I returned home enchanted. Robinson Crusoe and the desert island disappeared. The theatre now engrossed my whole soul.

My joy, therefore, was unbounded, when the Dutchess Amelia, that favorite of the Muses, established a theatre at Weimar. Several of the most celebrated performers of the time came there, and, among others, the admirable Eckhof. I never omitted any opportunity of going to the play, and I wondered that those who could do what they pleased, could prefer any other species of entertainment. As a proof of my attention, I could repeat the whole of Lessing's Emilia Galotti without ever having had the book in my hand. To the honor of the fashionable world at Weimar, I must confess indeed that Emilia Galotti was very often performed, and always to full houses.

Meanwhile I was a pupil of Musaeus in the Gymnasium at Weimar. Among other things, we had every Saturday an hour dedicated to the reading of little poetical attempts. At this period the rage for ballets was at its height, and the magazines swarmed with terrific stories of chivalry and ghosts. I composed a ballet in the taste of the times. It contained abundance of murder and ghosts; a Spirit read a lecture on vice, and the sinner was at length carried away by the Devil.

I read this performance the first Saturday after it was ready; and judge my raptures when, after it was finished, Musaeus pronounced those words which I shall never forget: "Well, very well! From what magazine have you taken this?" With what triumph did I reply, that it was my own composition! "Really!" answered Musaeus: "Bravo! go on." Nothing could exceed my transports at this panegyric, and my poetic propensity was confirmed.

At this time of life every thing is imitation, and I am convinced that there is not a single original idea in a man's head till he is of an age to propagate his species. Every thing I now made was only an imitation of the book I had last read. I wrote a comedy called All's Well that Ends Well, which I believe had a strong resemblance to the Count of Olsbach. Goethe used to visit in our house; he heard of my comedy, and was so condescending, or so polite, as to ask a reading of it. By this wish he highly gratified my mother; and this probably was his object, for I never heard more of the comedy. This able man, however, in my boyish days always treated me with great kindness.

In my sixteenth year I went to Jena. At first my attention was principally directed to the acquisition of the dead and living languages, and in both these my knowledge was considerably increased. At Jena my partiality for the stage
still continued. Before my arrival, there was a private theatre established among the students, and it was one of my first objects to be admitted into the association. As it is not customary for ladies to appear in such theatres, on account of my youth, female characters of the younger sort were often assigned to me. My propensity for rhyming likewise continued, and I produced a number of poetic trifles.

In my eighteenth year I undertook to write a Romance, which I finished. It consisted of eight or ten sheets, and, in my opinion at the time, was nothing inferior to Goethe's Werther. The story indeed was much more terrific; for my hero precipitated himself from the top of a high rock, and was dashed to pieces. This performance I sent to Weygand, then publisher of most fashionable romances at Leipzic. After waiting some time, however, I had the mortification to receive an answer from him, in which he told me that the manuscript was at my service, and desiring me to order payment of the postage of it! I never, however, enquired after it.

In the year 1779 I returned to Jena from the visit I had paid to my sister then lately married, and applied with considerable zeal to the study of jurisprudence. I likewise attended the professors of history, logic, and metaphysics, and continued to improve myself in modern languages.

I this year produced a tragedy called Charlotte Trank, which was performed at our private theatre, and I myself enacted one of the principal characters. The reception of it, however, was rather cold. Soon after I wrote a comedy, which was much better received, and, as far as I recollect, contained some tolerable comic touches. I likewise instituted a poetic club, from which I derived considerable improvement.

In my nineteenth year I returned to Weimar, and studied the Pandects with great industry; was examined by the Government, and admitted Advocate. While I waited for clients, I myself continued a zealous client of the Muses. The summer after my return, I wrote several little things, which I am not now ambitious to recall into notice. I likewise wrote some Tales, which were published with my name by Dyk, at Leipzie, with an hundred and fifty pages by some other hand. Several little dramatic pieces were likewise the produce of my partiality for the theatre.

In 1781 I went to Petersburgh. For some time I repressed my turn for poetic pursuits, but I again began occasionally
to indulge my ruling propensity. There was a German theatre at Petersburgh. It was then in a very indifferent state; but soon after it was put in the number of the royal theatres, and the direction of it given to my friend General Bawr, of the artillery, a German. I now again found myself in my element.

I wrote a tragedy in five acts, called Demetrius Czar of Moscow. By a whimsical circumstance the representation of this piece was nearly prohibited. In the history Demetrius was by many called an impostor. In my play I found it convenient to make him a hero. It turned out, however, that there was an old proclamation of Peter the Great, in which this same Demetrius was declared to be an impostor. With much difficulty, however, the piece was allowed to be performed; after I had in a very formal manner been made to declare that I was perfectly satisfied of the imposture of Demetrius, and the justice of the proclamation, and that the freedom which I had used in my play was merely a licentia poetica. I like wise wrote a comedy, called The Nun and the Chambermaid, which was performed with great success. It was never published, and the copy of it was accidentally lost.

In the year 1782, some of my friends who had influence at court, proposed to procure me a place, and to facilitate their exertions I was requested to write a small volume of Tales and Fables for young Princes, to be dedicated to the young Grand Duke. Though I felt no great call for such a task, I complied; and the volume was printed in a most superb manner by the direction of one of my friends. Finding, however, that I was not qualified for this kind of writing, I resolved, after the work had proceeded a considerable length, to repay the publisher for his expence, and to bury the four sheets which were finished in eternal oblivion.
Ye who so often and so loudly accuse me of vanity, to my Fables I appeal as the proof of your falsehood! Their suppression cost me some hundred rubles, but my vanity not a sigh.

I now come to the period when I went to reside at Revel. Soon after this I wrote two plays, The Hermit of Formentera, and Adelaide of Wulfingen. The former was performed at a private theatre, and my propensity for the stage revived. To this propensity the people of Revel are indebted for a theatre, which for the last ten years has had an excellent company, and can boast of performers of no common merit. It was opened with a piece of mine, called
Every Fool has his Cap. The piece bore a striking resemblance to Moliere's Miser, and I have buried it among my papers.

In autumn, 1787, I was seized with a severe illness, which for several years reduced me to a state between life and death; or, what is worse than death, a state of gloomy dejection of spirits. In the very height of this malady, I wrote Misanthropy and Repentance The Stranger., and soon after The Indians in England. Both of them were finished within about eight or nine weeks. Never in my life, either before or since, did I feel such copiousness of ideas, such vigour of imagination, such fertility of diction: and I believe it to be undeniable that there are some kinds of maladies (among which may particularly be included those which increase the irritability of the nerves) which elevate the powers of the mind to an unusual height; just as, according to the story, a diseased muscle forms a pearl.
In the year 1790, I wrote The Virgin of the Sun, The Child of Love Lover's Vows., and Brother Moritz the Humourist. I likewise proceeded in the collection of my smaller works.

Upon Misanthropy and Repentance many foolish things were said and written at the time. Among other things, it was objected that it was defective in poetic justice, because, by an unconditional forgiveness, I had restored the criminal to the enjoyment of all the pleasures of life. Whether any forgiveness could completely remove the cruel punishment which her crime carried with it; whether such a woman as Eulalia Called Adelaide, or Mrs. Huller, in the play as performed hero., with a conscience so awakened, could ever again be happy, are questions which nobody thought it worth while to ask, except Mr. Ziegler, who, however, took up the whole affair erroneously, and, by the unjustifiable freedom of calling Eulalia's seducer from the dead, completely changed the nature of the case. I therefore wrote the Noble Lie Translated for the New-York theatre under the title of The Stranger's Birth Day., in which, although certainly there appears a girl fallen from virtue, a circumstance on which the impure imagination of Reviewers continues to dwell, unquestionably prevails the purest moral that ever was inculcated from the pulpit or the stage.

In 1790, I experienced one of the severest dispensations of Providence, in the death of an amiable wife. Grief for this loss drove me to Paris, and the account of this excursion
I published under the title of The Flight to Paris. This book was likewise severely attacked by some critics.

Full of indignation against the Parisians, of whose excesses I had been an eye-witness, on my return to Mentz I wrote The Female Jacobin Club, a farce not without some humour. My friend Huber, however, because he happened to be of a different political creed from me, fell foul of it in the most violent manner. Nevertheless, despotism is to me as hateful as it is to him; and this I testified soon after in my Philosophical Sketch of Louis XIV. My publisher at Strasburgh sent me the work in manuscript, and the correspondence which I had with him on the subject, was broken open before it reached me. I complained to our minister at Frankfort on the subject, who took my side; but it was alledged at Mentz that the letters were open before they arrived there, and I never was able to learn who it really was who did me the honor to mistake me for a spy, or a red-capped Jacobin. It seems to be my fate, that while Mr. Huber and Co. exclaim against me as an advocate of despotism, the despots around consider me as a dangerous democrat, worthy of their most jealous attention. I could give signal examples of this, if a man were at liberty to tell all he could.

Once in my life I had the weakness to write a book in complaisance to another. It was the book on Nobility. I could say a great deal on this subject, but I am not at liberty to do it. If the world knew—and perhaps they may one day know—into what equivocal reputation of a certain kind I have been thrown by the opinions, which both before and since I have expressed, and which have been so egregiously misrepresented; if they knew how my most confidential private correspondence was turned against me; if they knew what inducements I had, and from whom they proceeded, they would decide upon that production upon quite different grounds; they would take into view not only the author, but the citizen and the father. I confess, however, that my inconsiderate complaisance laid me open in several points to the attacks of criticism; but for attack from those with whom I had lived in habits of friendship, I was not prepared.

All that I have written since has been received by the public with approbation, and by the critics announced without approbation. These are, Count Benyowsky, The Death of Rolla Pizarro in Peru., The Youngest Children of my Fancy, Poverty and Honor, The Man of Forty Years, The Negro Slaves,
The Chace Der Wildfang., The Count of Burgundy, The Defamers The Force of Calumny., False Shame, and La Peyrouse In addition to this catalogue we can add—Sultan Wampum; The Reconciliation; Family Connexions; Self-Immolation; The Children of Misory; and The Peevish Man, which have been published; and six which were finished and sold to various European theatres as long ago as the 11th of June 1799: The names, as given in a letter of that date addressed to William Dunlap, are as follows: The Epigram, in four acts: The Reward of Truth, in five acts: Johanna von Montfaucon, in five acts: The Writing Desk, in four acts: The Two Klingsbergs, in four acts: and The Wise Woman in the Woods, in five acts.

Many of my plays have had the good fortune to be translated into French, Dutch, Danish, Polish, Russian, Italian He had not, when this was written heard of the great success of his dramas in this country.; a new thorn in the side of the Reviewers! A few days ago I received the following piece of intelligence in a letter from Moscow: "Your play, the Child of Love, was as often represented, and with more applause here than The Marriage of Figaro in Paris. It is very well translated into Russian."

Is it not matter of surprise, that at the same time, and in so many countries, the Public should every where have judged wrong, and approved of things upon which the Reviews had pronounced irrevocable sentence of condemnation?—The investigation of that phenomenon, however, I must reserve for the continuation of this article on some other occasion. What may follow I must beg to be considered as the defence of a man accused; for the critics have so often charged me at the bar of their judges and mine, the Public, that it would seem a contempt for that tribunal never to take the trouble to answer. In this view I certainly may have some claim to indulgence. Yet shall it be my endeavour, as far as it is in my power, to intersperse with flowers so dry a subject, and never forget what Beaumarchais so well observes: "Faut-il, parce qu'on a raison, donner des vapeurs à son lecteur? et faire secher d'ennui les magistrats? Leur état n'est que trop pénible!" Because you are in the right, are you to give your readers the spleen, or kill the judges with ennui? Their situation is irksome enough already!

div.head: THE WILD-GOOSE CHACE. AS FIRST PERFORMED AT THE NEW-YORK THEATRE, JANUARY 24, 1800.
div.p: MUSIC composed by MR. HEWITT. SCENERY by MR. CICERI.

div.head: SCENE FIRST.
div.stage: The Hall of an Inn, with a front door, and several side doors, numbered. FREDERICK is discovered, standing with folded arms, before a side door, looking at the number.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: NUMBER three! A mysterious number! I shall not stir from this spot until I know who lives here. A figure as lovely as if painted by the pencil of Angelica Kauffman. Is she a wife or a maid?—O! certainly a maid.—In church she never turns her face from the preacher; but if by chance my eyes meet hers, her cheeks glow like apple blossoms.—What is it to me who she is? Ah! Fred, Fred, something whispers here (pointing to his breast) "that is not true".

lg.head: SONG. FREDERICK
lg.l: Prythee Fred, what is't to thee,
Whether widow, maid or wife?
Ever roving, ever free,
Liberty be thine for life.
Ah Fred! Fred! Fred!
When next you meet her eye,
Her pouting lips and cherry cheeks
Will give your tongue the lie.
Cheek, and lip, and eye as fine,
Other girls possess:—
All—yes, dam'me, all are mine—
Not a bonnet less.
Ah Fred! Fred! Fred!
The candor of her eye,
The innocence which marks her mien,
Will give your tongue the lie.

div.stage: LISETTE opens the door before which he is standing, and calls.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Molkus!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (Behind.) Here!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Bring coffee! (Goes in again, and shuts the door.)

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Directly!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (Imitating her.) Molkus!—Ha! ha! a pretty snip-snap dialogue. This I suppose is the lady of the bed-chamber, miscalled chamber-maid. We must buy her voice in the cabinet.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Which way, good fellow?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Fellow! I don't remember drinking fellowship with you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Don't take it amiss. We may know each other better.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Perhaps that may not be the better for one of us.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: True. Whither do you carry coffee?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: To No. 3.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Who lives in No. 3?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Sometimes one body, sometimes another; just as it happens.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I want to know.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Do you? I will tell you, sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: It is a maxim, that when one man has knowledge and another wants it—he must pay for it.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: No more than right. Thus let the pupil pay the teacher. Thus let ignorance pay tribute to knowledge. Here are three florins.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: No. 3. One, two, three. So! He that asks reasonably shall be answered truly. One, two, three. Ah! No. 3.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well! Who lives in No. 3?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Three women.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Who are they? What are their names? Where do they come from? Whither are they going? How long do they stay here?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I know not. I don't know. I can't tell. I haven't asked. Nobody knows.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Nay, but my good fellow—

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: No better than my neighbors.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You, at least, know their names.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Their names. Yes. They have three names.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Probably.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Written in the clerk's book.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: The old one is called Mrs. Von Brumbach.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Von Brumbach! That name promises nothing good.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: The little rogueish wench is call'd Lisette, and is her chamber-maid.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And the youngest of the graces with an angel's head?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: What angel's head?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The Grecian girl with the swan's neck.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Angel's head and swan's neck! We have no such birds here.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Stupid dolt! Who is the third lady?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Dolt!—(Weighs the money in his hand.) One, two, three. (Pockets it.) Yes, the affront may be pocketted.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well! The third, the third?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: The third is—the young lady.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But her name?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Her name is—probably the same as her mother's.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Miss Brumbach! No, that must not be her name.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Give her another.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That I will, by Heaven! That I will! Do you know nothing more?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Nothing, but that—the coffee grows cold.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Miss Brumbach!—The name sets my teeth a chattering—makes a lump of ice of me. How shall I cure this beautiful girl of her ugly name? And have I not the power? Yes! I will be her physician! Before to-morrow night shall she be Baroness Wellinghorst!—That sounds better. But how shall I begin it? Not a word have I spoke with her yet. (Peeps through the key-hole.) There I see a green sofa—but nobody sits on it. On the right hand hangs a looking-glass, but no image is reflected from it.—I must watch a little.
sp.stage: (As he puts his eye again to the key-hole, the door opens.)

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Ah! (Screaming.) What does this mean?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A formal siege, my lovely girl: but you make a sally, and the enemy retreats.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Have I done you any harm, sir?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Irreparable.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Oh, dear!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: With those sparkling eyes, you rogue!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: May I ask with whom you wish to speak, sir?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: With you, dear girl.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Well, here I am.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Pray tell me, who do you serve?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Mrs. Von Brumbach.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And who is Mrs. Von Brumbach?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Now, indeed, you ask me too much. I have only been with her three weeks: nor could my predecessor give me any information, for she had only served her ten days.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And you three weeks! That does you honor.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: My patience is already as thin as a cobweb, and if it was not for the sake of the dear young lady—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Aye, the dear young lady! The lovely young lady!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Do you know her?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I know nothing but her! The whole of my existence is devoted to the study of her; my soul can contain no other knowledge.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Where have you seen her?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Yesterday at church.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Never before?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Smiling.) The acquaintance is very young.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: So am I young: and the young lady is young; and you are young; and—in short, I am damnably in love with her.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Indeed! We cannot read that.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But I know it by heart.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Have you often such attacks?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I'll tell thee what, Lisette. I have been in love ever since I was eight years old, and I hope to continue so until I am eighty!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: The last object of your love will be envied.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The last object is your young lady. I shall love her forever.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Forever!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Not an hour less.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Eternity is a pretty little thing in the mouth of a young man of twenty.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: One and twenty, if you please; one and twenty.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: One and twenty! I humbly beg pardon. But may one ask, how the knight is called who bears my young lady's chains?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Baron Wellinghorst. I am rich. Have neither father or mother. To-morrow I am of age, and may do what I please.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: So, so! Now if the young lady could do what she pleased.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Do you think she would be willing?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Why not? Here an old cross mother: there a pleasant young gentleman. Here a glass of rhubarb: there a glass of almond-milk.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I am charmed! I must kiss thee!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Resists.) Do you always kiss your beloved's chambermaids when you are charmed?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Always, always—its my way.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Young gentlemen kiss: old ones give money.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: O! in that I'm as old as Methusalem. (Gives her a full purse.) There, you rogue—am I not grey?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Feigning resistance.) No—no. Indeed it was not meant—but you are irresistible.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: O, that I could hear your young lady say so!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Who knows—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Tell her that I languish like Siegwart, rave like Werter—

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: And love like Tom Jones.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That I am modest and discreet—

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: That you sparkle like a rocket—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Which dissolves in brilliant globes of light—

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: And goes out in an instant.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You should never continue a comparison too far. Now let us speak of my gratitude—It shall be as lasting as my love.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Four weeks.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Jesting aside. It is in your power to put me into a perfect rage of thankfulness. (Takes out a letter.) If, for example, you would deliver this letter.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: With all my heart. But where is the direction?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: It is addressed from me, through you, to my future spouse.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Without a name. Then I can give it to whom I please.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Not to old Mrs. Von Brumbach: rather keep it yourself.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: No; no, my pretty young gentleman of twenty one; a man in love must not go post haste like a letter.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Cupid is drawn by doves; and doves fly. As soon as the little god shall yoke snails to his chariot, I also will slacken my pace.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: My young lady does not yet even know that you exist; and shall she begin a correspondence with you?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Only let her read.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: The letter is probably copied from her eyes.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Word by word.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Then I know it by heart.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But an ambassador without credentials—

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Patience! Patience!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That word stands not in my dictionary.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Then write it in. Keep your letter, and I will tell her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Listen—

lg.head: Lisette.
lg.l: That a handsome young man,
With eyes black and bright,
Will love her forever
And ever.

lg.head: Frederick.
lg.l: That's right

lg.head: Lisette.
lg.l: That he is a baron
As bold as a knight,
And as rich as a prince:
What say you?
All right.
That he is almost
Twenty-one, but not quite—
And will wed her with pleasure
To-morrow.
To-night!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: If the old lady should not prove covetous of her blessing, and withhold her consent.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Chance has made me a baron, and given me two rich manors;—what objection can she have to me?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: She will say, children must not marry.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Two years hence she may say so to her grand-children.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: The mother is not willing to share the myrtle crown with the daughter.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What! Is the old one upon the lookout for a second marriage?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: A third.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Bravo!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: The first husband she vexed to death. The second ran away from her. She will take better care of a third.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Indeed? And yet travels in company with her daughter!—She would sell cucumbers, and yet carries melons in the same basket.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: We think the melons are not ripe. We call Nannette, the "little girl," the "child."

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Nannette! Is her name Nannette?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Nannette! O, what a heavenly name. I'm charmed again! I must kiss you! Nannette!—I must kiss you again!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: What! charmed again already?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Yes, I'm made up of raptures, charms and enchantments! If your young lady had a dozen such names, twelve times would I kiss you for each.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Lud a mercy! Softly, sir. If any one should surprize us they would think you were in love with me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: To be sure. Why not? I am in love with you. I once was in love with eight girls at the same time.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: A pretty recommendation.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But if you should be of opinion, that a divided heart burns the weaker, the fire of these kisses shall convert you. (Attempts to kiss her.)

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Resisting.) Baron! Why, baron!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: (Opening his room door.) Frederick! Frederick!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Ah! (Shrieks, and runs off into No. 3.)
sp.stage: Enter FELIX in a morning gown, from No. 1.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What! my dear Mr. Felix, are you up already?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: That is the question I would put to you: for you generally sleep some hours longer than I do.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Alas! my dear tutor; love—love robs me of sleep.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: What, again? Three miles from hence I heard the same story.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Three! Was it just three? That was ominous.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Look at the figure of three on that door.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: There dwells my beloved.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: What, she who ran in there just now?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Oh dear! no. That was only her chambermaid; a star of the sixth quality compared to the luminous sun of my affections.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I am used to hear of angels, stars, and suns.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And pray, Mr. Felix, if Mahomet could put the moon in his pocket, why may not I marry the sun?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: You will burn your wings.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You jest: but I am in earnest.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Heaven forbid.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Because we find among twenty marriages but one that is supportable: among an hundred, but one that is happy.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You are a woman-hater.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: A burnt child dreads the fire: but the youth rushes into the flames.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Flames! I'm a flame myself. A torch. A blazing tar-barrell. O! its so delicious to be all on fire!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I have experience—dearly-bought experience.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Only think, sir! Only think! Her name is Nannette.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Her name may be Angelica, and she no angel.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Only sixteen years old!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: So much the longer will she torment you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: As beautiful as a rose-bud!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: So much the more will the butterflies flutter around her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: As gentle as a dove!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Women are all gentle—out of doors.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Out of doors! Then will we take the air all day.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: My young friend, you jest upon the most serious affair of your life.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Serious? Just the reverse. To love a beautiful girl: be beloved by her: marry her!—What can be so charming?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: It is well that I know you, and know how soon these sparks go out.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That was because they formerly were only sparks; but now—now its a Trojan conflagration!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Dear Frederick, no more romance. We have travelled together many a mile, and have seen more than our post-horses. Don't let me have it to say, that you know the world and not yourself.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: If the seven sages of Greece had seen my Nannette, they all would be as mad as I am!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: And when you shall have been married to your Nannette one year—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I shall have been happy three hundred and sixty-five days.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: And in the second year?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Three hundred and sixty-six—if its a leap year.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Might my own terrible example be of service to you. I was once married—perhaps still am so.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Perhaps!—Odd enough.—Don't you know?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I play'd the lover of romance with my wife, and stood gaping at the moon, instead of examining her heart, until the sun of reason arose and showed me that I was wretchedly deceived.

lg.l: She hung on my arm, and with accents so sweet,
Cried, "the daylight can't vanish too soon;—
I long thus to lean, while you lead me to greet
The mild beams of the silver-faced moon."
At eve all was hush'd, and night's goddess shone bright,
I beg'd—she consented too soon.
I thought that the spirit I thus made my own,
Was as mild as the beams of the moon.
The moon-beams soon vanish'd—the bridegroom awoke—
Whilst the bright sun of reason arose,
Hymen's bands I found chains, and his garland a yoke:
And the moon but reminds me of woes.
Now at eve when I ramble o'er hill or thro' brake,
I deplore that I married so soon;
And in reason's despite my heart sometimes will ach,
While regret casts a cloud o'er the moon.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You opened your Xenophon, and read the life of Socrates.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: My Xantippe presented to me daily the goblet of poison. Vanity, obstinacy, and, above all, that accursed trick of pouting, at length drove me from my home, to seek rest on the troubled billows of an unquiet world.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You left her, then?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: It was wrong. I confess my weakness in the hope of preventing yours.—I left her all my property, which was far from inconsiderable, and an only child—a daughter. The little knowledge I had acquired was all I took with me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Particularly your knowledge of women.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: The assumed name of Felix protected me from enquiries; and I found an asylum in your father's house when you were but a little boy.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: My father died, and left to me the enchanting duty of continuing his undiminish'd friendship to you.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: You can if you will, dear Frederick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: We must always remain together. I could not be happy without you.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I love you as my son; and, as such, warn you of danger. Your father's last words still sound in my ears.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: "Obey this man," said he to me; "so shall my blessing remain upon thy head."

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: To-morrow you will be of age, and my authority ceases. The friend can only warn and entreat.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The friend! You make me proud by the title. But, my dear Mr. Felix, why must my marriage be unhappy because yours was so? If my Nannette should ever ask me to gaze at the moon, I shall remember you, and think she means to blind me.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: But you do not know your newly beloved.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What! Have I not seen her?—But not a word more; you yourself shall see her, be enchanted, and become my rival! That soft blue eye, modest grace, charming timidity, lovely innocence!—Shaped like a Greek; blooming as a Circassian; the bosom of a Turk; the teeth of a Moor—(Sees a servant girl, with a bunch of keys, cross the stage.) What a pretty creature! Stop—hark, my dear! Don't run. Ah! you little devil—I'll be with you!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: There it is! Every white apron sets him on fire. Foolish boy! who takes the heat of youth for love: and woe to the poor girl who shall throw her myrtle garland into such straw flames.

div.head: SCENE SECOND.
div.stage: Mrs. BRUMBACH'S apartment. A door and window in front.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Counting the money given her by Frederick.) Eight dollars and a piece of gold! I like this young man. He is as rash as an ensign, and as liberal as a prince. Let me see.—What is a chambermaid's duty in this affair? Here burns the fire, and there lays the straw! Then she must put the straw a little nearer to the fire; give a puff—and the business is done.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Lisette, is Mama up already?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Yes, miss, she is combing the lap-dog.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: (Yawning.) What day is to-day, Lisette?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Monday.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I'm sorry for it.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: It is so long before Sunday!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Did the last sermon please you so well?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: The sermon! O, no! But at church one sees the people of the town. All the rest of the week we dare not stir out of the house.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Yes, one sees and one is seen.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I wonder who would look at my plain hat and simple white clothes? Indeed I am quite ashamed that mama gives me nothing better.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Perhaps she thinks mama nature has given you enough.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: When I sit, in these clothes, among the fine dressed ladies, I feel that mama is right when she calls me stupid ugly thing.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: There are people who pretend the contrary.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Piffleberg once told me that I was pretty; but mama was angry, and he retracted his words.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: I know a young gentleman who will say as much, and not retract for all the mamas in Germany.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Do you know him? Ah, dear! how happy you are, Lisette! You are acquainted with so many people.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Within this half hour he talk'd more to me about you than I could repeat in a year.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: About me? O, gemini! Tell me, Lisette! Tell me!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: He is young, well made, all in a blaze, and he says "damnably in love."

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: In love? with whom?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: With you.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: With me! Oh, gemini! Lisette how you have frightened me. We must go and tell mama immediately.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: O yes, and run and tell Molkus! Tell mama, indeed!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: But does he love me, Lisette? Ah! now, you are joking.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Not I. He wishes to marry you.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Marry me! Marry me! Ha! ha! ha! That's droll enough. But, Lisette, can I marry already?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: I see nothing wanting but a good husband.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: You make me laugh.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: He is rich, and moreover a baron.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Are barons better for husbands than other men?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Not all. But I will lay any wager, that this one pleases.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: You will win, Lisette; I am sure you will win, if he loves me.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Love you! Why when I told him that your name was Nannette, he was in such an extacy that he caught me in his arms, and kissed me like a madman.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Kissed you! Is that a proof of his love for me?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: That's droll. But I don't like such proofs.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: He asked me to deliver a letter to you.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Where is it, Lisette? Quick, quick.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: "I take a letter?" says I: "no, no indeed," and I scolded him soundly.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Now, how could you do so? Nobody ever wrote to me in my life. Poor young gentleman! I dare say he'll grow melancholy.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Never fear. Melancholy don't seem to be his business.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Oh, gemini! Lisette, what will be the end of it?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: With time comes experience. You will know by and by. Your mama will not hurry from hence, because her romance with Mr. Piffleberg begins to become serious; so that you may, perhaps, have an opportunity of seeing and speaking with one another.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: See and speak!—I am sure, Lisette, I shall neither be able to open my mouth or my eyes.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: That will be his business. Come, come, who knows what may happen. He has fine estates, and when you are baroness Wellinghorst, I will marry the steward.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Yes. But then—then, Lisette—he need not prove his love for me by kissing you.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: No, no—hush. You shall have all the proofs. Hush, here comes mama.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Good morning, mama.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Good morning, child. Good heaven! how vulgar you look to-day: as red and healthy as a milk maid. I suppose you slept all night?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: That I did, as sound as a top.

lg.l: Did peaceful slumber e'er decline,
Her poppies o'er the couch to shed,
Where guiltless innocence reclines her head,
And health and exercise to call her join?
The pillows of the great she flies,
Affrighted by their beds of state:
Ambition's sons in vain her savors wait,
And guilt in vain for peaceful slumber cries.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Ah, there it is! there it is! How can a child of a genteel family think of sleeping half her life like a dormouse?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Indeed I can't help it, mama. After supper I am so sleepy, that if I did not go to bed, I should certainly nod in my chair.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: That's because you cat. A shocking vulgar custom. You may know a lady of quality by her complaints. Thank heaven, I have not known an hour of health in my life.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: That accounts, madam, for the air of soft languor which diffuses itself over your person, and renders your manners so interesting.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Dear Lisette, you know men are tyrants; and how should we weak creatures dare to trample under foot the rights of the strong, if we could not render our delicacy interesting? Nervous complaints, cramps and hysterics have metamorphosed many a lordly master into a supple slave. But these are things which little girls can't understand: go, child, into my closet, read in the prayerbook, and take care of the lap-dog.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Yes, mama.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Has not Mr. Piffleberg been here?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: He went a hunting very early this morning.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Poor man! Anxiety deprives him of rest. It is strange how hard some people take the soft passion. What think you, Lisette, shall I marry him?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Consult your heart, madam.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p:
Oh, horribly vulgar! No, no, those times are past, when the heart was suffered to play the master and lead blindfolded reason in chains. Love is a good servant, but a bad master. Marriage is a hateful custom; but, being established,
one must conform to it, as to the afternoon's nap in Spain. But woe to the fool who bends her neck where she was born to govern.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: But with Mr. Piffleberg?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: True, there I run no risk of enslaving myself; and that is no small recommendation. His estate, it is true, is mortgaged; but he is an honest creature, and since one must have a male animal about one, as well him as another. To be sure he is a little too rough and noisy, but he has a great deal of nature about him, and I love nature!—Lisette, where are my other teeth?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: In your bed-chamber, madam.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: This man seems really attached to me: but I must make trial of his talents for obedience.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: And if he stands the trial—?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Why—I am tired of rambling about thus alone: I want a husband to settle my accounts, and take the trouble off my hands of quarrelling with innkeepers and postillions. Then when I consider that I have a little child to provide for—

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Bless me, madam! have you a little child?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Do you forget Nannette?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Oh, the young lady—

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: What young lady? A child who hardly knows her right hand from her left. I hope, Lisette, you don't put things in her head.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Oh dear, madam! Mercy forbid! Why she hardly knows that she has a head.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Ah! Lisette, a mother's duty is a heavy burthen: then there is the lap-dog and the canarybirds.—My future spouse will have enough to do.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: You might easily get rid of the young lady.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Give her a husband.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Art thou mad? Ha! ha! that child a husband! Don't mention such a thing. Early marriage—late repentance.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: It would be a pity, to be sure, for poor Mopsy the lap-dog's sake, he is so attached to her.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: That alone would be sufficient. Come, Lisette, let me attend a little to my dress. No, no, as long as the dear lap-dog lives, Nannette must not think of marrying.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Oh dear! Oh dear! And she is called a mother! Well, they say charity covers a multitude of sins. Then will I weave a plot to release poor Nannette from this tyrant, the charity of which shall cover all my peccadillos like a cloak.

lg.head: SONG. LISETTE.
lg.l: Come dear invention!
The chambermaid's first blessing;
Which makes her feel as Croesus rich,
Tho' nothing else possessing.
Hither! Fill my plotting brain!
Make the dragon's watching vain:
Until Hesperia's golden fruit be mine;
And love with beauty bless'd pay homage at thy shrine.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Hoix! tally ho! tally ho! The widow! What is the old puss still in her form? I'll rouze her with a sportsman's serenade.

lg.l: The morning is bright, still the dew on the ground;
My pointers bound lightly and share In my joys;—
A brace of staunch dogs!—Now, a covey is found—
See!—they point!—fix'd as stone—not a wink of their eyes!
Go on!—They're up!—I single one.
He's down! My aim is sure.
Mark! Mark!—Again I've mark'd them down.
My game is still secure.
While hills, dales, and woods the sharp echoes repeat,
My priming is laid and my charge is renew'd.
Follow! Juno and Dashwood! In vain they retreat—
In triumph I bear home the choice of the brood.
Go on!—They're up!—I single one!
He's down! My aim is sure.
Mark! Mark!—Again I mark them down.
My game is still secure.

sp.p: Ye hoix!—Tally ho!—The widow!—Here she comes! I've brought her down!—I'm the shot, crack! (Always accompanying the last word 'crack' with a smart clap of the hands.)

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Bless me! what a vulgar noise! Have pity on my nerves, my good Mr. Piffleberg?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Good morning, widow! A fresh morning. I have been bathing my feet in dew.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: You speak as poetically as if you had been reading Kleist or studying Thomson's Seasons.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Kleist? I have a cousin serves in that regiment. As to Thomson I don't like him—he's a damn'd brute of a poacher.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Thomson a poacher!

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Yes, I have caught him at it. But he's a good miller, and so I keep him on my estate.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Oh, lud! Oh, lud!—Have you good hunting on your estate?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: The best in the land. Marry me, widow, and I'll shew you sport!—Not such a shot in all Germany; crack! Or for a fox-chace—Devil take me widow—you are no chicken;—but you never saw such sport, old as you are.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Old!—It seems, sir, you are as poor a judge of a lady's age as you would be of a Chinese poem.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: There you have me. I never was in the West-Indies. I speak plain German.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: German enough, heaven knows!

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: I can tell the age of a horse to a hair. There a body may look at the teeth.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Will you walk into the stable?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: What should I do there? To be sure the landlord has a pair of bays—

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: They will understand your language.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p:
So ho! Dam'me the widow's up. I've been at some of my old blunders I suppose. I'm off the track—must call in. Don't take any thing amiss, widow. I am plain, but as honest as my spaniel; staunch as my pointer. A good fowlingpiece
should have a rusty coat; your polish startles the game—but clean within, widow; clean within! And what signifies a little rough casing, so as the heart has but its proper loading, well wadded and ramm'd.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Why if a lady could understand—

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Let us make an end of the matter. Tomorrow shall be the wedding; and the next day the fox-chace.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Good heavens! you are so hasty!—

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Why the truth is, widow, we have neither of us any time to lose. I have been a long time out of my teens as well as yourself.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Why, pray sir, how old do you take me to be?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Why you told me yourself, that your second husband was killed in the seven-years war.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Very pretty, sir! Why not in the Trojan war?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Trojan war! When was that? Was that one of old Fred's? But damn all wars, they spoil sport. I love peace, and will marry you, even though you had gone to school with Methusalem. Therefore, widow, make no difficulty. Come with me to Piffleberg. My curate—a damn'd good shot—shall publish the banns, and then in God's name—be fruitful and multiply.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Not quite so fast, Mr. Sportsman. To win a lady or to shoot a partridge are two very different things. There is nothing so disgusting as one of your marriages which are concluded like a matter of bargain and sale; where there is no elopement, no moonlight assignation, no duel, no suicide to enliven the scene a little.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Suicide! A very lively affair to be sure, widow; but it may do as well after the ceremony. As to the duel, why I'm a damn'd good shot, crack! but who is there to sight with?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: But setting aside those bagatelles, there are a thousand things to be done.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: In God's name, let's begin then, or the sporting season will be over. I am ready to receive your instructions.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: We must be undisturbed.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Well; who disturbs us?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: This is a public hall: people constantly passing and repassing.—But observe, sir. Yonder door leads to the garden. Here is the key to it. When the clock strikes twelve, the noon of night and hour of ghosts, I shall expect you here.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: At midnight! Why dam'me, widow, I am always a-bed by ten o'clock. "The hour of ghosts!" yes, and the hour of thieves too.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Oh, sir! if you are afraid—

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Afraid!—No, I am only afraid of oversleeping the time. (He takes the key.)

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Very well, sir! If so, sir, you may seek a mistress in the dew to-morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: But why must I come through the garden? The house is a public house, open all night, nobody to stop me.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: What, sir? would you expose my character? Besides, the garden is so much more pleasant; the pure air and the nightingale's song—and I shall myself be there.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: The nightingale don't sing at this season.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: To be short, sir, the way to my heart lies through the garden.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: What, widow, is your heart a hot-house? To tell you the truth, if I don't get my usual rest at night, I am not worth a charge of powder the whole day after.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Very well, sir: no sacrifice—no merit.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Come, come, widow, let us leave these fooleries to younger people. I believe our ages put together would amount to something more than a century.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: What, sir, would you make me a Cybele?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: You have the gout, and I am troubled at times with a rheumatism and a cursed back-ach; and the night-air is as bad for that as for your asthmatic cough.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Oh heavens! what indelicacy. I shall saint—I am sick—

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: There it is, now! And yet you would be running about in the damp air at midnight.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Nannette!—Lisette!—Help!—I am dying.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Never fear—I will mix you a tea-cup-full of brandy and gun-powder—never knew it fail—here's my pistol. (His pocket bottle.) Give me a tea-cup. I am the best horse-doctor in—

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Nannette! Lisette! Help! help! Hartshorne! Salts!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Dear me! my lady, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: What ails you, dear mama?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: My salts—give me my salts!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Holding it under her nose.) The young gentleman has certainly been taking liberties.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Young! (Half aside.) Not much younger than she is. And she is as grey as a Russian hare in the winter.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Get out of my sight, sir! Get out of my sight, sir!

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Her back's up now: we must smoothe it. (To her.) Why but, widow, what the devil—I meant no harm—

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Out of my sight, sir!

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Give me leave and I'll send you as fine a sow as ever you sat eyes on.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Keep your swine for companions.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Dam'me, she's in earnest. Even the sow won't soothe her.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: I insist upon your quitting my apartments.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Well, well, be pacified—I'm off—but I shall return.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: (Going.) I have thought of a plan for reconciliation. If that don't do—Let the huntsman sound his horn and couple the dogs—Hoix! Tally ho! Ringwood! Echo! Dashwood!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: What! Is he gone? and without throwing himself at my feet?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: You must forgive him that, my lady, he is stiff in the knees.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Alas! how many things must we forgive the tyrannic sex.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Dear mama, do the Russian hares grow grey in winter?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: You are a goose.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: If my lover had said such a thing to me, I would have discharged him without much ceremony.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Lover! Your lover! Is it possible? What do I hear? We shall soon have babes in the cradle lisping to one another "I love." Each doll will be a Cupid, and every sugar-cake a love-letter.—Pray, my pert miss, do you know what those things called lovers are?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Not very well, mama, but I am ready to learn. (Curtseying.)

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Heaven forbid, child! A lover is worse than the sun in the spring; the one spoils the complexion, the other the heart.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Yes indeed, miss, and if he don't spoil it, he takes it away.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: A lover is a cunning animal, always lying in wait to take advantage of your weakness.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Is one always weak when one has a lover?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: It will happen so sometimes.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: If he lies at your feet as a slave—there let him lie.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Poor man!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Lift him up, and he becomes your tyrant. A lover is a second Proteus, he insinuates himself in every possible form.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Beg pardon, ladies; am I right? (Putting his head in at the door.)

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Smiling.) Yes, indeed, in every possible form.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Whom do you want, friend?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The celebrated and amiable Madame Von Brumbach.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: I am Madame Von Brumbach.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Aside to Nannette.) It is the baron.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: (Shricks.) Ah!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: What ails the child?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: You have made her so afraid of lovers, that even this powder-puff frightens her.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Must I run away, mama, if I see one?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Not if I am present.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (Archly.) I think, madam, they say that children cut their eye-teeth very soon in this country.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Children are very forward. But pray, my friend, what do you want here?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I wish to have the felicity of putting your silken hair in curls.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Your trouble is in vain. I have a hairdresser.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Certainly, madam, he is my master. He is sick, madam, and has sent me in his place.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Ah! so, so! What ails him?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: He is—sick, madam, sick—very sick.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: But his disorder?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Yes, madam—true—he has the—the—broken-leg, madam—the broken-leg.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Poor man! How did it happen?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: He happened to be—Heaven knows why—upon the top of St. Agathy's steeple, and, in descending, his foot slipped and he fell down seventy-seven steps. Seventy-seven—I counted them myself.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Top of a steeple! Well, he that ascends high may fall low. But what business had a hair-dresser at the top of a steeple?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: They wish to be always busy about the head.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! ha! The lady is right—even about the head of the church. I should be happy
to take the pope by the nose. (Imitating the action of shaving.) But my master was in the line of his profession, madam, even at the top of a steeple. Did your ladyship ever see St. Agathy's church?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Lisette bring my dressing-gown. (To him.) Never. (Lisette goes for the gown.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Nearly at the top of the steeple is a statue of the saint, with a beautiful sox-coloured wig, which, being out of curl, my master was sent by order of the vestry to put the holy hair in buckle.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Having put the gown over her mistress and seated her in front of the stage.) Good fellow, have you long exercised your profession?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (Beginning to dress.) I hope soon to be a master.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Then I suppose you will marry?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (Looking at Nannette.) If I can obtain the object of my love.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: What countryman are you?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: From Alsace, my lady—an emigrant—if I should be known, I am undone.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: You must be on your guard.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I shall take care to deceive those who will suffer themselves to be blinded.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: There you are right. Have you many customers?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I forget them all when with your ladyship.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: You are an odd fellow. Do you dress the Lady Hengsberg?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The Lady Hengsberg? O, yes.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: How old do you think she is?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: How old? Why—a—your ladyship might be her daughter.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: (Smiling.) Oh, no! not so much as that. She is some years younger than I am.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Is it possible? (He shews Nannette a letter. She appears anxious, pleased, and timid. Lisette takes the letter, and reaches behind Frederick to Nannette, who approaches and takes the letter from her.)

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: But it is very natural that she should look so old; the dissipated life she leads—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Her husband ought to restrain her.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: She has no longer a husband.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: True—true—that is true enough—she is a widow—

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: No—she is divorced.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ah! true; divorced. A widow or divorced, or divorced or a widow, it's all one.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: (To Nannette, who is going off with the letter.) Where are you going, child?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: To my room, mama.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Stay here. There is nothing for you to do there. Stay here. (To Frederick.) So, the revolution drove you from home?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Yes, madam. They wanted to force liberty down my throat; but I (Looking significatly at Nannette.) prefer slavery.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Why certainly hair-dressers are the servants of luxury—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I would willingly fly to England, but since Pitt has laid a tax on hair-powder, the English have all become crops; and, unless wigs can be brought in, the profession must starve.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Lisette, pray give me—(As she turns she sees Nannette reading the letter.) Pray, miss, what have you got there?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: (Frightened.) Nothing, mama—nothing.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Nothing. Let me see immediately what nothing looks like. Bring it hither instantly.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: It is not nothing, mama. It is—it is—(Distressed.)

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: It is—a paper—(Confused.)

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Will you not obey me? (Rises.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: O ho! What, miss, have you got the letter out of my powder-bag? that's a good joke—Ha! ha! ha! (Takes the letter.)

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: What letter?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I don't think the young lady would have done it, but that little thief of a chambermaid of yours has taken it out—

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Taking the hint.) Little thief, indeed—a pretty appellation: though I did take the thing out of your nasty bag, I won't be called thief, so I won't. (Pretending to weep.) You powder-puff: you wash-ball: razor-strop—(Pretending rage, and following him as if to box his ears.) Bravo, baron, it will do!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Am I to know the meaning of all this?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Sit down, serene lady, and compose yourself: you shall know all, though I betray my indiscretion.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: (Sits again.) Well, well!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I rely upon your generosity—you shall know all.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: (To Lisette, who now stands with her.) Sure he won't tell, Lisette?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: I think we may trust him: he has taken his degrees, and is master of arts tho only a bachelor.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
Between ourselves, my lady—but for heaven's sake do not betray me—this letter is addressed to the Lady Hengsberg. I saw it this
morning as I went to dress her: it lay open on her toilette—my eye caught a phrase—curiosity was awakened—and, in short, I whipt it into my powder-bag. If you will permit, I will read it to your ladyship.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: You may read it my friend—you may read it. Nannette, go to your chamber.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: O dear! my lady—a little girl like that would not understand it.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: I am unwilling to let children hear such things. But, however, you may stay and take a lesson against the wickedness of the world and the impudence of lovers.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (Reads, and addresses the whole to Nannette.) "Beautiful and amiable creature."

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: "Beautiful!" See, Nannette, what gross flattery.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: "I have only seen you once, but my heart is yours forever. As you came out of church yesterday—"

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: That's áll she goes to church for.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Leaning on the arm of your ugly old mother—"

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: That's true enough, the mother is an ugly old woman, and as mischievous as a cat.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: And as vain as a peacock.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And as stupid as a goose.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Mischievous, stupid and vain. An excellent picture. Ha! ha! ha! Go on.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: "You looked like Hebe led by the old Cybele. I am young, rich, and love you unspeakably. Accept the hand of a youth who means honorably, and will deliver you from the tyranny of a mother."

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: That I never heard of the mother—she does but too much as the daughter wishes.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: "Let us endeavor to deceive her."

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: That will not be difficult.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: I think not, my lady.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: "And if she continues her odious tyranny and preposterous jealousy, fly into the arms of him who adores you."

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: An elopement too! How I shall laugh at the old woman.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: I think the young gentleman has explained himself clearly enough.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Very clearly.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: (To Nannette.) It must be clear, indeed, if you could understand it.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: What would you say, miss, if any one should write you such a letter?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I would not suffer any one to laugh at my mother.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Then you would dismiss the flaming youth?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Why—no—not so—

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: How can you embarrass the poor child by such questions?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Indeed, mama, I am very much embarrassed.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: So, Lady Hengsberg is in a secret correspondence with a young unknown. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I have found him out already.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Indeed! Who? who?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A certain Baron Wellinghorst.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Well, I must mention this to three or four of my most intimate friends.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: A ha! me lady, pardonnez moi, I hope you have not vait.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Bless me! monsieur, are you out of your bed?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: "Me bed!" Ma foi, vy I av a been up—up—up—

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Yes, I know it—up to the top of the steeple.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Steeple!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: To dress St. Agathy's wig.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Parblieu! me lady, vat vig?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Did you not put her holy hair in buckle?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Vat buckle?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: And fall down seventy-seven steps?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Seventy-seven—?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: And broke your leg?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Diable, vat you mean?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You might have broke your leg, ha? you might have broke it.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Me broke a me leg? Aha! (Capers.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But you happily escaped with a sprain. A sprain; ha?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Sprain! Vat you call sprain?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Why then did you send your journeyman?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Me shoorneyman?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (Making signs to him.) Yes, sir, you know you sent me to dress this lady.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: For vat I sent you, ven I have a good pair of legs myself; ha?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But you do not dress hair with your legs, sir.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Me lady, dis is some treek—dis a fellow is imposteur.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (Getting before him, and offering him money with his hand behind.) Understand me.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: For vat I understand? Get out of de vay. I understand you for von dam impudent fellow. Ma foi! Vere is your certificate?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Here, here. (Endeavoring to put money in his hand.)

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: No here, here; nor dere, dere—I vont sell a de trade to vagabon—I vont sell a de bread out a me mout.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Oh, Lisette! I am in an agony.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: This man then is not your journeyman?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: No more dan is your lap-dog ma shoorneyman. He is imposteur—vagabon—

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: What has induced you to intrude yourself into my presence?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (Somewhat in caricature.) It is vain any longer to attempt to deceive a lady whose penetration would baffle the art of the most experienced in the wiles of Cupid, much more of me a simple youth. I will confess, my lady.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: It is all over with us, Lisette.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I am a poor unfortunate lad. I saw you, my lady, in your yellow sattin gown—I had a glimpse of you—need I say more?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I remembered the old saying "a cat may look at a king." I gazed and was undone. If it is a crime to love, let nature bear the blame, who gave me such a heart, you such a face.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Lisette, give me my fan.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: To hide her blushes or her wrinkles? (Brings the fan, while Frederick proceeds)—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: My passion went hand in hand with discretion. I only wished to see you; to be near you: and, as the means, fell upon this innocent stratagem.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Innocent! Ma foi! take a de bread out a me mout!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But never should my lips have uttered these words, but for this untoward discovery. For now I must he banished forever from your presence. (Kneels.) Punish me now! Complete the work your charms have begun!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: You are a foolish young man. But rise. I pardon you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Alas!—I must then go! (Looking at Nannette.) But I leave my heart behind.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Who told you you must go? You are a foolish youth, but you may be improved. You see, monsieur, there is nothing to be done with this young fellow.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Nothing to be done? Ma foi! I go to de magistrate, and put him in de ouse of correction.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: If I pardon him, surely you may.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: He take a nothing from you me lady, but he spoil a me trade. Pity me me lady—Listen and pity.

lg.l: Tink, me lady, only tink,
Take avay me meat and drink;
How shall make de kittle boil?
Vat shall do for vife and shile?
Do I haven't break me leg,
I shall have me bread to beg.
Den he tell de lie so big;—
Say I dress de steeple vig.
Now, me lady, as I live;
As I hope me sin forgive;
De only vig I dress in town,
Gracious lady, is—your own.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Vulgar fellow! In short, sir, here is your money. I have a right to be dressed by whom I please, and I take this young man for my valet de chambre.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (Kisses her hand.) You give me life again!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: He dress hair? Only see vat a fright he as made of your vig.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: That's nothing to you, fellow. Begone!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: I vill complain to de police—

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Do you not hear, fellow? Begone!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: I vill ave you vipt out a town.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: My valet de chambre whipt? You are an impudent fellow.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: A fool!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: A brute!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: An envious fellow! (Pushing him.)

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: You take a de bread out a me mout—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A way!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: As to de lady, you ver velcome to dress a her old stinking hairs—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Out of the house!
sp.stage: Enter PIFFLEBERG and his HUNTSMAN, with six hares. FREDERICK throws the HAIR-DRESSER on PIFFLEBERG, who throws him to the HUNTSMAN, who throws him out.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Who says the hares are not fresh as a rose? Smell one, widow, (thrusting a hare into her face). Just shot 'em, crack!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Good heaven, sir, how vulgar!—And pray, sir, what has brought you back?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: How could I be easy under your displeasure? I bring half a dozen hares as mediators between you and me.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: The price you set on the peace, shows the value you set on me.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Now I think six hares—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And a bear in the bargain—

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: There are no bears in this country.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: If I thought that true repentance brought to my feet—

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: There they are, all at your feet.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The most repentant hares in christendom.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Young man, for a valet de chambre, you take too great liberties.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: A valet de chambre! (after observing him) So, ho! Thunder and lightning! Are not you the young baron who drank burgundy with me last evening at the coffee-house?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: A Baron?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I drink burgundy, your honor? I am glad when I get a drink of small beer.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Upon my soul, but it is you! Had we not three bottles?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Your honor mistakes.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Not I. Did not you say, that here in this tavern lodged a beautiful girl with her ugly old mother? Did not you drink the young lady's health?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: What does this mean?—Have I been deceived—abused—

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Aye, that you have. He called you an old—

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: No repetition, sir.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: So, we are fairly in the mire now.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Lisette, I shall die!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I tell you sir, you are mistaken—you are blind—

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: I blind? The best shot in Germany, crack!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I tell you, you are blind—blind, sir, blind! (puffing powder in his eyes) blind! blind! blind!

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Thunder and lightning! What do you mean?—I am a gentleman—a sportsman—powder and ball!—Satisfaction!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: I shall faint!—I see the affront but too clearly—I see it all.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: I wish I could see any thing.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Such an affront! I shall die!

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: An infernal poacher!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Where is my faithful friend?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: (Aside.) I thought she would come about. Here I am, widow.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: The only one that never deceived me.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: My faithful lap-dog! my Mopsy! my last consolation!

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Damn the old witch and her Mopsy!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: It is very well, sir, I shall tell my mama that.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: It is very well, my pretty miss, but your word will not go far now. Who is the cause of all this? ha! A sly poacher has spied your tracks, and sneaks after you through brier and bush—

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: And an old huntsman cries Halloo! ho! To spoil sport and frighten the game. That's all you are good for.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: All I'm good for? Dam'me the best shot in all Germany, crack! Do you see these hares?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: I killed them.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: What a heroic deed! So the butcher may say, "do you see this beef? I killed it."

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Butcher? I am a sportsman.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Therefore without excuse for staining your hands with the blood of the innocent. You rejoice at the sight of death, and destroy animal life for sport. I'll sing you a sportsman's song.

lg.l: The sportsman arm'd, and fill'd with joy,
Forth issues to the plain:
To seek, to start, pursue, destroy,
And triumph o'er the slain.
With a "Ho! Halloo!
My dogs are true:
Tantivy! Tantivy! Hark forward apace!
She starts—she falls—she gasps for breath!"
What pleasure to view the convulsions of death!
For murder's the joy of the chace.
The partridge leads her callow young,
First forth in search of food;
With mother's joy she struts along,
And eyes the helpless brood.
With a "Ho! Halloo! &c."
The timid hare her covert flies,
And bounds with speed along;
Bends back her ears to catch the noise,
And hears of death the song.
With a "Ho! Halloo! &c."
Creation's pride, God's last, best work,
Thus time and strength employs,
Like wolf to prowl—like fox to lurk;
Crowns reason's lord with joys.
With a "Ho! Halloo! &c."

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: So! very pretty! And here they leave me standing alone like a mile-stone; covered with powder, and as white as a hare in a snow-storm. If the old woman had not a heavy purse, she would not find me here as a rival to Mopsy. But what can a man do? We shoot a raven that is carrying gold to her nest. Well, I must humor her, and make use of her garden key to open her strong box.

div.head: SCENE FIRST.
div.stage: Scene continues from the last act.
Enter LISETTE, who crosses the stage and calls.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Molkus!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (Behind.) Here!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (With a doleful tone.) Oh, Molkus!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: What's the matter?
