sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Still more doleful.) Oh, dear Molkus!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Changing suddenly.) How d'ye do, Molkus?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Pretty well.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! Good day, Molkus.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Nothing else?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Is a good day nothing?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Nothing—if it comes from you.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Why you thing; you piece of a man:—bad day to you. The worst day that ever the sun hid his face from!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: As bad—as that on which you lost your leg.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: That day bad? That was my day of honour!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! ha! Of all the foolish animals in creation, surely that species called man is the most so. A fellow hires himself to be shot at for six-pence a day, which is three pence less than boys give in England to shoot at a cock on Shrove-Tuesday—one day a cannon-ball takes off his leg—that is his day of honor. A foolish girl,
who sighs for she knows not what, on a day called a wedding-day, bends her neck to the matrimonial yoke, and becomes the slave of a dunce—that is her day of honor. Another, still more foolish, takes the veil and becomes a nun; on a certain day she is decorated for the sacrifice, renounces her reason, her senses, her friends, and the world—and that is her day of honor. The first gets a medal, the second a husband, and the third—nothing at all. Thus do the few make fools of the many, and the fools are dismissed, as fools ought to be—with fools-caps.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: What did you call me here for?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: To make a fool of you.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: And that being done—(Turns solemnly to go.)

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: No, no! not half done yet. (Turns him about.) Every man is a fool, is he not, Molkus?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Each deriving food for his pride from the weakness of his neighbor. The wooden-leg'd looks down on the straight-leg'd; the straight-leg'd on the crooked-leg'd; and the crooked-led'g again on the wooden-leg'd. A rondo of pride and folly. Am I not a philosopher, Molkus?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: A chatter-box.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Where are you going?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Do you know, then, what I have to tell you?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Do you wish to know?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: But you shall know. My lady orders you to wait here for her. She wants to go out immediately.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: But it is not well; and these answers are not well. "Away"—"No"—"Well." What answers are these?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Short ones.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Your answers are measured by your short leg.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: I'll tell you what—if your head had been shot off as well as your leg, you would have felt the loss as little.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: You are right—if I only spoke with women.
sp.stage: Enter MADAME VON BRUMBACH and NANNETTE.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Molkus!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Here!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: I am going to my mantua-maker's.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: You see here a couple of foolish girls?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: If a young man comes to see either of them, do not let him come in.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Probably, he will wish to profit by my absence. If he comes, throw him out.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Out of the door, or out of the window?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Where you will. I am not particular.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Child, do you read meanwhile in the works of Madam de Beaumont, or Madam de Genlis, pour former le coeur et l'esprit. And Lisette!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Do you take care of the lap-dog.

div.stage: MOLKUS puts a stool before the door, sits down, takes a short pipe out of his pocket, fills it, takes out steel, &c. strikes fire, and lights the pipe.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: You do not even ask if we like the smell of tobacco.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Miss, can't you faint?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I do not understand that yet, Lisette. I must learn of mama.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: What a charming opportunity this would be to speak to your lover. He is certainly not far off.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I'm sure he is not—feel how my heart beats.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: How shall we get this blockhead out of the way?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Give him good words.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: I would rather give them to the lap-dog, for he, at least, wags his tail for them.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: We will try.—Dear Molkus!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Pretty Molkus!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: What more?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: You sit so uncomfortably there.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: So, so.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: A veteran, like you, who has deserved well of his country, ought to be borne on the soft hands of the fair.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: A wooden leg is worth more than a woman's hand.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: In my lady's chamber stands a soft sofa.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: There let it stand.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Let us lead you thither.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: And give you a drop of my lady's choice cordial.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I am not dry.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: You deserve to have your face engraved upon brass for your honesty.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: And put under a glass and frame.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Then would we hang you under the looking-glass.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Oh, that you already hung there!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Half aside.) Or on the gallows.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Dear Molkus, let me go out on the balcony?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Dare not.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: To take a little fresh air. We are suffocating with tobacco smoke.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Very good tobacco.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Dear Molkus! pretty Molkus! charming Molkus! can you refuse me any thing?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: You block, stock, stick, stone! You mutilated lump of inanimate matter! You stickbeaten drum-head—weather-beaten knapsack—

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: So!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Don't mind her, Molkus—

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I don't.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: You are an honest fellow.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: A'nt I?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: I wish the ghosts of the poultry you have stolen could arise and cackle at you. Do you relish your pipe?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Take it to the watch-house. (Knocks it out of his mouth.)

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (Takes it up coolly) If you do that again—

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I will pick it up again.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Dear Molkus, if you will do nothing else for us, at least grow angry.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Anger is like fire—it burns him that bears it.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Not if he bears it in a heart of stone, my pretty man of marble. In how many battles have you run away?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Run away?

sp.speaker: Lis
sp.p: Yes, for thou never had'st any motion but in thy lost leg, and then thou wast a notable runner. I will give thee the history of thy creation, and that will account for thy present immoveability.

lg.l: When art made thee man, that is, gave thee man's shape;
Or rather, a form between mastiff and ape;
For thy face she chose brass, and that thing thou call'st head,
She fashion'd it out of a lump of crude lead.
For thy heart she took iron. For flesh, blood, and bone,
She gave thee a carcase of stick, stock, and stone.
Then to nature she went for some feeling to beg,
And obtain'd just sufficient to move one good leg.
That leg thou hast lost; and the mass that is left,
Of feeling, thought, kindness, and motion bereft;
Remains a poor object, deform'd in each part,
By nature rejected, a scandal to art.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Thank you. I like music when I smoke.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: It is not worth while either to speak or sing to you.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I like silence, better than either.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Thou canst neither hear, see, taste or feel. Thou art only fit to smoke bad tobacco.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: The tobacco is not bad.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Thou hast not as many senses as an oyster. (Knocking is heard.)

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Does an oyster hear?-Somebody knocks.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Get up and go out.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Getting up and going out are two different things. (He rises and puts his head through the door)—Who's there?

sp.speaker: Harsh voice without.
sp.p: A friend!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: What friend?

sp.speaker: Voice.
sp.p: An old invalid, who wants to speak to honest John Molkus.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Invalid!—Wait a moment comrade.—(Shuts the door.) Miss Nannette and you miss Magpye, march to your chamber.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: With all our hearts: we are tired of you and tobacco smoke.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: We will go and see Mopsy.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Fate has destined us to see nothing better to-day.

div.stage: MOLKUS opens the door, and FREDERICK enters as an Invalid, with a wooden leg and several scars on his face.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ah ha! Old comrade, how goes it? Don't you remember me?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What, have you forgot Georgy Frolic, of the regiment of Steinacker? Don't you remember him?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Georgy Frolic? hum!—Can't say I do.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What! Don't you recollect our lying before Prague in the year '57?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Before Prague? Ah! I shall never forget that. Our regiment encamped on the righ • of Ziskeberg.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The Austrians made a sally on the batteries of Strohof.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: And Prince Ferdinand of Prussia drove them back!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: How again they attacked us on the side of Wisherad.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Aye, and how our cartridges took them in flank!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: How the Prince of Lorrain, with 4000 men, attempted to surprize us.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: And how we sent them back with bloody noses!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: O, what a pity that bad weather came on!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: And the Moldau overflowed its banks.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And carried away our bridges.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Right, comrade. Yes, you were there!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I not there! My ears yet tingle with the noise. I could fancy myself still there!

lg.l: Still in my ears the cannons rattle,
And rouze my blood again to battle.
Hark! 'tis the roll of the hollow drum!
The shrill trumpet sounds!
To death, blood, and wounds!
From their trenches the enemy come!
Now every man at his post is found,
While swords and muskets glitter round.
See 'tis our standard beats the air!
Now the general comes,
The chorus of drums,
The salutes of the squadrons declare!
Now, now! the glorious game's begun!
They run! Too soon the cowards run!
See! where our horsemen charge their rear!
While shouts, cries and groans,
Music, thunder and moans,
With confusion o'er power the ear!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Bravo, comrade! Yes, you were there.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I there? Was it not our batallion that attacked the Austrians at the wind-mill of Segeshuzen? Thus we stood, and thus we marched towards the wind-mill. (Marches towards the door.) Ah ha! Holla within there! Where are the enemy? Peep out of your holes!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Softly, softly, comrade! That is not a wind-mill. There are ladies living in that room. (Pulls him back.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Adso! Thank you, comrade. Then I shall wheel about. I would rather attack the Croats.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Ah! there you think like me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: If I only hear of a woman, I run—(aside) mad.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Just like me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I would rather lose my other leg than attack a woman's chamber.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Where did you lose your leg?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: At Kollin.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: At Kollin! Just the spot where I lost mine! (Looking at his own wooden leg.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Is it possible? (Looking at his leg in imitation of Molkus.) Is it possible? Who knows, but both our legs are buried in the same hole?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Ah! Who knows?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But come, never mind legs so as the heart is sound. Come, brother, what say you to a drink together for old acquaintance sake. (Draws out a bottle from his pocket.)

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: With all my heart. To the health of old Fred. (Drinks.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Long live Fred! (Drinks and gives the bottle to Molkus.) Fred's a knowing one.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: At Kollin I was one that attacked the church-yard under General Hulsen. (Drinks.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I was in the brigade of Manstein.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: You had hot work with the Pandours. (They continue drinking.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Yes. Don't you see this cross scar on my cheek?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (Drinks.) Ah! curse the Pandours.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I was before Shweidnitz with them when they storm'd the water fort.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I fought in the trenches before Olmutz. (Drinks.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I was at Cuibau when we were attacked by Laudon as we convoyed the forage.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: But, brother, you look young for one that has seen the whole of the seven-years' war.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I'm older than I look for, comrade. 'Tis wine gives me this youthful appearance, in spite of time and scars. Drink, damn it, drink! He that would remain young must drink!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Yes, drink. (Drinks.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: No women and much wine, that's my maxim.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Yes, much wine. (Drinks.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I'll give you a song. Meanwhile don't spare the bottle.

lg.head: SONG. FREDERICK.
lg.l: Of old it was said, "wit, women, and wine,
Are the sources of man's purest joy."
But believe me the pleasure that's truly divine,
Flows from wine that has known no alloy.
Yes, Bacchus alone is the source of delight!
Let your Vulcan's and Venus's squabble.—
Let Mars blow the coals;—while Apollo so bright,
Finds his wit the sure source of a hobble.
'Tis women and wit are the source of all jars;—
Let us link them together for life;
Your would-be-wit woman all happiness mars,
And your wit is the pest of a wife.
But Bacchus is surely the source of delight!
Let your Vulcans and Venus's squabble.—
Let Mars blow the coals;—while Apollo so bright,
Finds his wit the sure source of a hobble.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (Drinking.) Bravo brother! Bravo! Your songs grow better and better! But where have you been since the seven-years' war?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I enlisted with the Hessians, and went to America.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: What, with one leg?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Why the Prince of Hesse sold his regiment by the number of men, not by the number of legs: and, as to myself, I was better fitted to face a field-piece than ever, for I couldn't lose above half the number of legs I might have lost at Kollin.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! Good! (Drinks.) Right! good!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ah! if I had had two legs I should never have seen my dear native country again.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: How so, comrade?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Why all our men who could walk away from the sea-coast, took good care not to return to their ships again.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Oh, the base villains desert their country! What could be their inducement?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: They had heard of a little saying very fashionable among the Americans, handed down from father to son, ever since the first settlers of the country took up their abode there to avoid persecution at home.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: What is that, brother?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: "Where liberty is, there is my country."

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Here's to that. (Drinks.) But how did you like the sea?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Oh! it's very wet.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Oh! very wet: and drunk, damn'd drunk.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: What, the sea?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The sea. Drunk! I say drunk! You don't doubt me, I hope?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Heaven forbid.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Drunk. For example:—(Staggering.) I want to steer this way—the sea—the sea throws me that. Then I would tack about, but I miss stays and a wave casts me upon a rock—and then—(Staggers against the door and bursts it open.)

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—Halt, comrade!—Ha! ha! ha! You are running on a sand-bank.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I am on already!—Help! help!—Who inhabits the coast?—Help! help!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—Don't you remember, comrade, there are no inhabitants there but women?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Let them come! Let them come! Dam'me, when I have had my bottle, I am not afraid of the best of them! Come out! Who's afraid?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Bravo! Let them come! I'm not afraid of them now!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I will give the signal of distress. Piff, paff, puff!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha I Paff, puff, piff!

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Piff, paff, puff!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: What means this noise? Why you drunken wretches, do you think this is a sutler's tent?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (Aside to her.) Lisette! Lisette! Don't you know me?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Shrieks.) Ah! Hush, I know you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: These wenches are so squeamish.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Miss, miss, come out quickly.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: What's the matter here?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Here is a drunken man whom you shall make sober.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Dearest Nannette, Proteus is in alliance with Cupid, and we play a comedy in masks.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Getting between them and Molkus.) Well, Molkus, how goes it?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Always upon two legs, my pretty chickabiddy!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The moments are precious. I love you unspeakably.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Is that an old fellow-soldier of yours?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Aye, girl, we fought side by side at Prague.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: May I interpret that sigh favorably?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Can I hinder you?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: And our legs now lay side by side at Kollin!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Will you become my wife?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: My mother will never consent.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Your legs?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Yes, buried in the same hole! O, curse the Pandours.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: I never saw a Pandour in my life.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Trust to love and me, and fly to my arms.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Against the will of my mother? Never!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: They are devils incarnate! But if a pretty girl comes in the way of one of them—like you for example, Lisette—

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: He becomes as tame as a lamb.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Aye, I warrant you!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: To-morrow we will implore your mother's forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Those who ask forgiveness, must first have committed a crime.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Upon the honor of a soldier, you are a fine girl.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: If you loved me—

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: If you loved me—

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Has not my heart betrayed me?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Patting Molkus's cheeks.) Do you think I hate you?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Fly with me this night, and to-morrow you are mine forever.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Don't you hate me, little rogue?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I am watched by a thousand eyes.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Who could behold the valiant Molkus with indifference?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Love blinds them all.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Is that true? Give me a kiss then.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Ah! but will you marry me?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Shall I attempt to carry you off to-night?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Marry—Ha! ha! ha!—I never was married in my life.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: How will you penetrate through locks and bolts?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That is my care.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Only try. We shall live together like turtle doves.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Turtle-doves! Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Have I your consent?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I entrust my innocence to your honor.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: But the kiss—the kiss—

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: There—how do you like it?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (Embraces Nannette.) Divine girl! The deposit is sacred!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (Seeing them.) Hallo, comrade!—What the devil! (Makes a step towards them.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What's the matter, brother? (Meeting him.)

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: What! Do you take the town by storm?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The fort is ours!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Victoria! Let's fire a feu-de-joy! Piff, paff, puff!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: (Without.) Take out the horses.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Heavens! the old woman comes!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Alas! my mother!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Whither shall I fly?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: She's at the door!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Victoria! The old woman comes! Huzza!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Is the window high?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Only one story. It looks to the garden.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Adieu! dear Nannette! (Jumps on the stool, and from it through the window.)

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Alas! I am afraid he has hurt himself.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Huzza! huzza!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: What noise is that? If the cat is not at home, the mice run over the tables and chairs.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Aside.) She has forgot the stool.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Victoria! The old cat has come home. (Staggers to the window.)

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Molkus!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Huzza!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Art thou drunk?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (Looking out.) That fellow with one leg runs like a chamois.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Who has given him liquor?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Molkus, go to bed.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (To Lisette.) Come, my little bride, the old woman says we must go to bed.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Is the fellow mad?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: To-morrow, dear Molkus, to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Yes, to-morrow the chaplain of the regiment shall come—"John Molkus, wilt thou marry this girl?—" Yes,"—" Lisette, wilt thou marry John Molkus?"

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: "Yes." Now good night, old and young! Cat and kittens! (Staggers to the window again.) Sleep well!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Where are you going, fellow?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: To see if my comrade is off.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Comrade?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Hallo! Georgy Frolick, where are you?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Molkus, you are wrong; this is not the door—this is the window. (Pulling him away.)

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Hallo! comrade.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: What does this mean?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: He is drunk, mama.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Drunk or not drunk, he stormed the water-fort before Sweidnitz, and con-consequently—

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Consequently you must go to bed. (Palling him.)

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Stop. We must fire a feu-de-joy.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: As much as you please out of doors.—(Pushes him out.)

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (Without.) Piff, paff, puff! Huzza! Piff, paff, puff!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Has any body been here?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Lisette, has any body been here?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Not a soul.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Why did you leave the chamber?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: We heard the coach and ran to meet you, madam.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: How does Mopsy do?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: He slumbers sweetly.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Come, girls, it grows late. Go to bed.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Already, mama?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Yes, yes. Children had better sleep.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Shall I not undress you first, madam?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Shall I not read the evening's prayers to you first, mama?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: No. Go to bed. I shall sit up. It is a fine star-light night, and I understand a little of astronomy. I know the Great bear and Jacob's staff.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Come, miss, your mama wants to see the Great bear.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Good night, mama.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Good night, child—to bed.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Aye, to bed! to bed!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p:
The hour of trial has nearly arrived. Obedience, Mr. Piffleberg, obedience is the test. If he does not make use of the garden-key, he shall find my heart shut to him forever. Confess it, Salome, thou wishest him to prove worthy of
the reward; for, alas! she who has seen eight and forty summers—hush—let no one hear it—age has betrayers enough; the tongue need not prove traitor. What is that? Why do the trees rustle so violently under the window? Don't I hear the window move? Yes, I feel by the blowing of the wind that it opens. Should Piffleberg, in order to give me a proof of his affectionate obedience, come through the window!—Oh, delightful thought!—What heart could resist such romantic love? I will listen, however.
sp.stage: Enter FREDERICK through the window, dressed as before, except the wooden leg.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (Putting his head in first.) Hist! hist! All quiet—All dark—In I come. Where the devil are they all gone already? Here I am again. But what farther? It's so dark, I can't see my hand. The right hand door is the place. Hist! hist!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Hist! hist!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (Softly.) Is any body there?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: (With disguised voice.) I am here.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: My beloved?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Oh, quickly fly to my arms!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Here, here!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Where, where? (He at length embraces her.) I hold thee in my arms, and no power on earth shall sunder us.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: (Screaming.) Ah! that is not Piffleberg!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Damnation! this is not Nannette! (Disengaging himself.)

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Help! Thieves! Robbers!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: By all the devils, it is the old woman!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Why, comrade, how did you come by that leg?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Who are you, fellow? What do you want here?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (Embarrassed.) Long—Madam—I have long—wished the honor of your acquaintance—

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: And so you come in through the window?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: If I dared—if my tongue—if I could speak—to you a moment without the presence of a third person.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: As good a leg as ever it was.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Put down the candles, and leave us.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: But, comrade, where did you get it? Could you not get mine too?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Go to bed, I command you.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: He has never been to Kollin already. There's witchcraft in it.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Now, sir, we are alone.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What shall I say to her?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Come, sir, no loss of time, for I expect to see a gentleman of honor here this evening. I would not have Mr. Piffleberg find me with such a companion.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Now, my lady, you have yourself named the cause of this my apparently strange intrusion. Mr. Piffleberg is the cause of my coming hither.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Mr. Piffleberg?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Yes, madam. Knowing the power which your charms have over one so nearly related to me—

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Related to you?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Yes, my lady, Mr. Piffleberg is my father! My mother was his house-keeper—but, as her charms faded, the cruel man abandoned her, to seek her bread in the wide world with me, pretty babe, at her back.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: She deserved it. What else could she expect for such conduct?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: As I grew up, I entered the service. I fought in Russia against the Turks, and in Flanders against the French. My scars bear testimony to my valor. Meanwhile, my father, notwithstanding my plaintive letters, afforded me neither countenance or support. Accident brought me at length to this town. I heard that my father, in common with all who see your ladyship, had become an adorer of your charms; and encouraged by the celebrity of your benevolence, I resolved to apply to you for your interference in my behalf.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: But why make your application by starlight, and through the window?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Pardon me, gracious lady, but not daring to hope that I could approach your august presence without introduction, I had made this assignation with Lisette your chambermaid.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Then it was Lisette you expected to meet?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Whom else, my lady? She has given me so exalted an idea of your heavenly virtues, that I could not but cherish the hope of your intercession in my favor.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Well, well, I promise to do something for you. I expect your father—you shall stay and witness—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Oh, no! no, my lady! by no means.—I will owe all to your power, nothing to the emotions which my presence may excite in his paternal heart. I will withdraw.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: By no means, you shall stay—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Excuse me—my father might—if he sees me so suddenly—

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Fear nothing—Know you not that love leads lions with a chain of silk?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: (Entering.) Now, where am I? Yhoix! Widow! Thunder and lightning! This is as cold as a duck-hunt.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Now impudence assist me.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: You are welcome, sir. You have come just in time to answer a few questions concerning your son.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: I?—I a son?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Aye, indeed, and too clever a young fellow to be thrown without protection upon the flinty world.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: What the devil's all this? Have you set me upon this wild-goose chace only to make a gander of me at last?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Look here, sir. Look at this youth and blush.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Blush! What should I blush for? Who is he?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Your son.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (Throwing himself at his feet.) Yes, my father! Do not stifle the voice of nature. Acknowledge me for your son. Bless your unfortunate Frederick.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Are we playing a comedy here?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Hitherto it has been a tragedy with me. It is you that can make it a comedy. Bless me, my father! Bless me!

sp.speaker: Pif
sp.p: Are you mad?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (Starting up.) You will deprive me of my senses, cruel father!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Can you shut your heart against the feelings of nature?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Why, dam'me, you are both mad!—May my piece miss fire but I smell a fox. This fellow is some knave that wants to make a fool of me, or you—I'll have him seized—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Do you hear, my lady, he abandons me! Me! the son of his house-keeper, who took care of his kitchen for kindness, and washed all his linen for love! He wishes my misery! he desires my death! Well be it so.—Cruel and unnatural father! To-morrow will they drag my mangled corse from the river! To-morrow will the cry of vengeance arise against thee!—Ha!—See!—It opens!—It blazes!—I see the devil, with his great iron claws!—He seizes me! he pulls! he tugs!—(Aside as he goes out.) I'll soon be with ye again my grey-headed goslins.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: And so you persist in not acknowledging him? You let him go thus?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: He may go to the devil. The fellow is out of his senses. I did not see it at first, but it is plain enough—The police ought to shut up such lunatics.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: No, no, sir. He spoke very sensibly before you came. Your cruelty has driven him mad.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Why, widow, you don't believe all that there stuff?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Why not, sir, why not?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Why, in the first place, I never had any house-keeper, but black Tom the game-keeper; and, in the second place, every body knows I'm as virtuous, as to all that there, as Jupiter de Mcdecine, or any other goddess of them all.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Oh! Goths and Vandals!

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Aye, or any Goths or Vandals you are acquainted with.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: You are as barbarous as you are deceitful. I do not doubt that he is your son.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Because he is a stout handsome fellow, perhaps?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: What reasons could he have for wishing to pass for your son?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Saint Hubert may know!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: In the first place you are not rich.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Granted. But I'm an excellent shot, crack!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Secondly, you have a hard heart.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: By all the elements, my lady, fish, flesh, fowl and red-herring! Would you have a man build a foundling-hospital, to prove that his heart is soft?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: But what advantages could he promise himself from such a plan of deceit?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: I tell you once more, Saint Hubert must know it better than I; but as I'm sure it's a lie, so I am certain there's no truth in it.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: You will talk differently if he throws himself into the water.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: No danger of that.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: If he should be dead to-morrow!

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Then will I be condemned, all my life, to shoot sparrows and dig moles.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: You don't suspect that my chamber-maid knows the young man?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: That is not unnatural. Chambermaids will know young men.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: She can unmask your hypocrisy.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: My conscience is as clean as my gun.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: We will try that. (Opens a door and calls.) Lisette, are you gone to bed yet?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Without.) No, my lady.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Come hither a moment.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: My lady?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: So, very pretty! you make assignations at night with men! You let young fellows come in through the windows!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Aside.) So! Now we are hobbled! Oh dear!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: For this time I will pardon you, if immediately, without any subterfuge, you make full confession.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Aside.) Well, since she knows it, be it so.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Where did you become acquainted with the young man?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: In this house, my lady—he was so friendly—

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: And how do you know that he is Mr. Piffleberg's son?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Surprized.) Ma'am?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Out with it! out with it! I will know what it is. I will not suffer that any vagabond from the high-way shall call himself my son.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Has he, then, himself confessed that this gentleman is his father?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Certainly, and referred me to you.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Since it is so, I must avow that to my certain knowledge, as far as one can be certain in these things, he really and truly is the son of that gentleman.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: The son of the devil!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: There, sir! there, sir! there it is! Perhaps you know his mother? Do you know her, Lisette?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: His mother?—O yes, madam—She is a distant relation of mine.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Now, sir! Now, Mr. Piffleberg!

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: May I be shot dead with peas if there's a word of truth in the whole story.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Confession and repentance might perhaps have obtained my pardon. But now—what must I think?—Who knows how many more such young fellows run about the world, cursing their father? Who knows how many poor deluded damsels set behind the spinning-wheel, and wet the flax with tears caused by your infidelity?
sp.stage: Enter FREDERICK, as a woman, and veiled.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (To Piffleberg.) Have I found thee at last, perfidious man? Have I at last found out your tricks, and detected you with your seraglio about you?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: What is this?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Again, a new scene!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Is this the reward of my fidelity and constancy? Is this the fulfilment of your oaths?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Thunder and lightning! Am I in a madhouse?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Who are you, madam?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
Pardon, my lady, an unfortunate woman, who has been most cruelly deceived. A
thousand times has he sworn to me eternal love, a thousand times promised to marry me. He gave me this ring as the pledge of his faith. (Weeps.)

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Woman, are you possessed with the devil?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Oh! how different were your words when you sighed at my feet, and persuaded me out of my innocence! Then I was an angel!—

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: An angel of darkness!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (Sobbing.) And now you abandon me! Now that your son, my pretty little Billy, is crying at home for bread!

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: By all the elements, another child!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: I am petrified.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: So am I—at his impudence.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I was warned of your intentions upon this lovely lady—I watched you—I saw you sneak through the garden, like a thief—I followed you—

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Woman! I'll tear your infamous tongue out!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Softly, sir! I take her under my protection.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: I'll have you sent to the house of correction!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Oh! gracious lady, save a poor unfortunate girl! What shall I do? If I go from hence he will murder me!

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Yes, you goshawk! That I will, you crow-face! you owl!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Do not be afraid, madam. Go to my daughter's chamber, there you will be in safety.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Oh! my lady, you are as good as you are beautiful.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Conduct her in, Lisette. (Softly.) And let her out through the back-door.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Aside.) I shall leave my lips without blood from biting them. (To Frederick.) Come, madam.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (To Piffleberg.) Farewell, thou tyrant! Thou beloved, too lovely traitor!

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Lovely devil!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Oh, thou hot-blooded monster!

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: This comes of being out of one's bed at midnight! This comes of going on a wild-goose chace by star-light! Nothing but sorcery and witchcraft! The devil has let loose all his legions to torment me.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: You will never persuade me that the devil is the father of your children. In short, sir, all is at an end between us.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Only make enquiries—

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: What enquiries? Haven't I seen children of all ages, mothers of all conditions—

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Where? Damn it, where?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Was not your son Frederick here? Was not the mother of little Billy before me?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: I wish the one was hang'd and the other broke on the wheel.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Truly that would rid you of the expence of maintaining them.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Oh! Oh, my lady! My lady! My lady!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: I can't speak.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Has the woman fallen into a fit?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: She has run away.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: So much the better.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: And carried off the young lady with her.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Yhoix! Tally ho! There you have it!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: What? How? Speak?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: She has carried her off to play with little Billy!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Speak? How?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: I opened the back-door, as your ladyship ordered, and then she threw off gown, veil, and all—and I saw that it was a man—and I saw how he clasped miss in his arms and flew away with her like wind.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Who was he? Who was he?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Indeed, my lady, whether it was Mr. Piffleberg's son, or the old soldier, or the journeyman barber, I cannot say.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Or the young baron that dressed your hair while he courted your daughter.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Why did you not cry out?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: I had just opened my mouth, intending to scream for the very blood of me—when he drew out a dagger, and swore he would kill me if I made the least noise in the world.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Miserable woman that I am! Unhappy mother! Is this the reward of my kind indulgence? What shall I do? My child! my child!

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: I told you it was all witchcraft, deceit and the devil!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Oh! my dear Mr. Piffleberg, if you love me—fly—run—overtake the seducer—chace the robber—

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: I'm afraid, widow, that would be another wild-goose chace. Besides, I thought it was all over with us.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: I have done you wrong—forgive an unhappy mother!

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Will you marry me if I bring him back?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: You will not insist on my running away with you?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: No, no!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: One elopement will serve for mother and daughter. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: It's a bargain! I'll soon be upon his track, and then, in spite of his tricks, I'll drag him out from his form. Yhoix! Tally ho! Tally ho!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Away, Lisette! Call Molkus! Both go in pursuit. Take the watchmen to help! Shut the doors! Run! Fly!—Oh, dear! Oh, I could tear the hair from my head for spite!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Aside.) Yes, if she had any.

div.head: SCENE FIRST.
div.stage: Scene, the Hall of the Inn as at first.
Enter NANNETTE, running from Frederick's chamber. FREDERICK follows her.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: No, I will not stay in your chamber.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I know not why, but my heart tells me, it becomes me not.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Does this place become you better?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: In this public Hall, where every moment some one is passing, there is no danger.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What danger is there in my chamber?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I know not. But if I am there alone with you, my heart beats so—it beats here too, but not so much.

lg.head: Frederick.
lg.l: Sweet girl, fear no danger,
While safe by my side:
To-night my hope's treasure;
To-morrow my bride.

lg.head: Nannette.
lg.l: But my heart feels so strangely,
Perhaps 'tis not fear,
Yet it beats, throbs and flutters,
Whenever you're near.

lg.head: Frederick.
lg.l: Sweet girl, fear no danger,
While safe by my side;
To-night my hope's treasure;
To-morrow my bride.

lg.head: Nannette.
lg.l: My heart fears no danger
While safe by your side;
But still it would flutter,
Tho' I were a bride.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Is heart-beating a sin?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I know not. But I had a governess who used to say, "Abstain from every thing which makes the heart beat or the blood rise in your cheeks."

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I suppose her worn-out heart had not blood enough to spare a blush to her wrinkled cheeks on any occasion.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I pray you bring a light hither.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: You always ask me "why?" And I know not. But something within whispers, "ask him to bring a light."

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And what will that "something" say, if I refuse?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: It will be unquiet and say, "Those who seek darkness will do evil."

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Can one not do evil by the light?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: No. Surely one would be ashamed of oneself.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But consider, dear Nannette, if there was a light here—but a step from us is your mother's chamber—How easily might we be betrayed!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: O me!—I almost wish I were betrayed.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You do not love me, then?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: O yes, I love you dearly:—but to be alone together, certainly is not right. I wish it were day-break!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Your impatience will spoil all. We shall be surprised, you will be torn from me, and then you will be lost to me forever.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I will be true to you, indeed and indeed!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Have compassion on my anxiety and come to my chamber.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Rather into the street, or the marketplace.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Strange—lovely girl—surely, after having run away with a man, you may trust yourself in his chamber.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Have I run away with you? Oh, how foolish I have been!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Do you repent it?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Almost. Alas! what will you think of me?—But, indeed, and indeed, it is the first time I ever ran away with a man!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Sweet girl! I believe it fully.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: You have so surprized me—I know not how it was—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: All uneasiness shall be forgotten to-morrow. I have thought of something which will spare your delicacy. I will conduct you to the bed-chamber of my tutor.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: The bed-chamber of a man?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Of a man of fifty.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Whom I don't know.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I will stay with you.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: But he will be asleep, and so we shall be alone after all.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Strange girl. There is a lamp burning by his bed.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: And if he should awake?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Then will I present to him my spouse.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: But it would be better if he would not sleep.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well, then, I will wake him.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Go. Wake him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Come with me.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: No, you must wake him, and then he must come and conduct me to his chamber.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
Be it so. But I would not wish to leave you here alone. However it is done in two minutes.
Only stir not from this spot, and if any body goes through the hall, hold your breath for fear of discovery. (Goes into Felix's room.)

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Oh dear! Hold my breath? I do not know whether I have any breath. I tremble like an aspin-leaf. Why then did my governess say "only the guilty tremble?" My heart tells me that there is no guilt in love.
sp.stage: Enter MADAME VON BRUMBACH from No. 3.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: I thought I heard a noise. (Listens.) No: all is still. How much anxiety this wicked girl gives me. If I once get her again in my power, I will immediately shut her up in a convent.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: In a convent? No. I would rather go into the young baron's chamber than into a convent.
sp.stage: Enter FREDERICK and FELIX, the latter with a lamp, and dressed in his morning gown.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Mr. Felix, my best friend, here is the timid girl.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Frederick, Frederick! What have you done?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Rather ask what I will do. I will marry her.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: After what is past, you must marry her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I'm very glad to hear it; for, dam'me, if I wish any thing better. Turn your lamp—look on her lovely face.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Dear, unknown gentleman, pity my innocence! be my father!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: A father, my child, is more easily deceived than a mother.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: (To Frederick.) Do you hear? He reproaches me with deceiving my mother! It pierces my heart! I will return to my mother. She will shut me up in a convent—there I shall weep forever! But here I can never be happy, if good men and my heart reproach me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: My dear Mr. Felix! listen to the voice of the purest innocence! If ever you loved me, now assist me.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I pity your weakness, and still more the inexperience of this good girl. I will assist you on one condition.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I consent to any.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: You must, as soon as the day breaks, throw yourself at her mother's feet, and ask her blessing on your union.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Willingly.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Till then I take the young lady under my protection.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Now my heart feels light again.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Will you confide in me?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: With joy, you appear so good! I can trust in you and love you.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Go, then, into this chamber. I will follow you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Go, dear Nannette, and sleep a little meanwhile.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I sleep? Feel how my heart beats. I never was in such a situation but once in my life before—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: How—once?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Yes—when I had the small-pox; and I could not sleep a wink all night.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Do not leave the poor girl alone, sir.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Only one word more to you, young man. Maiden honor is like polished steel, a single breath takes away its lustre.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Not the breath of love.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: That more than any other. If you were capable of sacrificing this unspotted lamb—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Never!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I hope not. If you should, I would instantly leave you, and call down in anguish the curse of your father!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: To-morrow she is my wife.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Rather say, when her mother consents.
sp.stage: Enter MADAME VON BRUMBACH. She comes to the door No. 3. as before, but seeing the light, starts back.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: I still think I hear—Saints and angels! A ghost!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That was the old woman.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: That voice is not unknown to me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I dare say you have heard ravens croak.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I will go to the trembling girl. Do you remain where you are, and come not in her presence until her mother's consent is obtained. But remember ever.

lg.head: SONG. FELIX.
lg.l: Bright is the honor of a maid, than polish'd steel more bright.
A single breath its lustre dims;
The mirror then no longer beams
With smiles of innocence and bland delight.
A damp corroding rust succeeds,
Nor can a life of holy deeds,
E'er make again the tarnish'd surface bright.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Obtain her mother's consent! That will be no easy matter. However, I have possession.—I follow the fashion of crown'd heads; seize upon the territory they have resolv'd to make their own, and then proceed to negociation. But what am I to do with myself until morning? I must not go to my bride, and I cannot go to sleep. O! what is so tiresome as the longing of a lover? While old father Time, like all other grey-beards, having no consideration for the impatience of youth, creeps on with snail's pace, and if one attempts to give him a lift, it is in vain; alas! he is as heavy as a ton of lead. Wishes are useless: impatience is vain: attended by prayers and curses he creeps at length to the point—the lover rushes to the arms of his mistress—and Time—runs away as if the devil was in him! No stopping him! No recalling him! No keeping up with him! On he goes! Whip and spur into eternity!—And sometimes takes love with him!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Something stirs. Hist! hist!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Hist! hist!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: It's a woman. I know the sex by instinct. From what charming lips comes that "hist?"

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Is it you, Baron?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: It is I. But there are many Barons. Which seek you?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Baron Wellinghorst.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And who are you?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Lisette.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ah, Lisette, is it you? Little rogue, come hither that I may kiss you. You have come in the very moment for making time fly.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Where is my young lady?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Safe with my tutor. But where are you running at midnight?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: My mistress has sent me to seek you, and Heaven knows what is to become of me when she finds that I have aided you in your rogueries! I cannot think of returning to her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Make yourself quiet. At this solemn hour of midnight, when witches ride upon broomsticks and devils dance upon hot grid-irons, do I, vested with a husband's rights, name, appoint, create, nominate and install, you, as chambervirgin, chamber-maid, lady of the bed-chamber or maid of honor, unto my most honor'd and ever-to-be-loved spouse, from this time and forever, in witness whereof I do hereby, press, kiss and embrace—(Attempting to kiss her.)

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Pushing him back.) I will alarm the old lady!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Take it, take it—only as earnest money.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: It is stolen money. And the receiver is as bad as the thief.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Take it, child. I coin this kind of cash every minute.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: It is of no value, unless love sets his stamp on it. But without jesting, Baron, I enter your service It is no more than just, for you have brought me into these difficulties.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well, be it so. I will bring you out again.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: But where shall I stay to-night. On the left hand is Hell. (Pointing to Mrs. Brumbach's room.) And on the right hand stands Satan. (Pointing to Fred.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
Suppose you steer a mid-course and go into Purgatory until morning? There is the wardrobe, where I dress sometimes. Two old cloaks hang in it on great wooden pegs. In one
corner stands an umbrella and in the other a lanthern. Will you pass the remainder of the night there?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Any where rather than with an old woman in a passion.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Go in, then. I will, put a stool in with you, and as soon as the day breaks, Nannette shall redeem you.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: A charming opportunity for repentance. (Looking in.) It is as dark as the grave!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Your eyes will make it light.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: I am no cat.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: There—take the stool and be as quiet as a mouse. Good night—sleep sound. (Shuts her in.) Now will I roam about the house, like a ghost that wants his bones buried. Not a mouse that gnaws behind the wainscot, not a cricket that chirps behind the oven, shall escape my notice.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p:
I would rather pursue a flying Hussar than a lover that has carried off his mistress. Oh, how my head aches! If I had had a comfortable nap after my wine—but to be running about all night through wind and rain—Oh, how my back aches. My sound leg is tired, and my wooden leg is smeared with mud. I will not run any more on the old woman's wild-goose chace. They may fly to the Desart of Arabia for me, and eat locusts with Saint John. Well, shall I return to the old dragon and report that I have found nothing? That would be to run out of the rain under the water-spout. I would rather encamp here for the night as well as I can. Ah, ha! A
chair! (Sits in an armed chair.) Lightning and grape-shot! this is as soft as if it was made for a gouty man. Now, thank heaven! (Yawning.) I can only have the gout in one leg. Ah! how warm and comfortable! (Yawns.) Ah, ha!—And General Sleep has commenced his attack—I shall yield at discretion.—True it is no bed—but after such hot service.—When I was in the seven-years' was—stood centinel on an out-post—there—leaned on my gun—and nodded—nodded—nod—(Falls asleep muttering.)

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: So! I give it up! Dam'me if all my hounds will catch this hare. He's an old fox—up to all the tricks. Beating about through thick and thin, and what have I got by it? Wet feet—car-ache—and rheumatism in my arm. I will not go and have my head combed by the widow in the bargain. No, no, there's no sport in that. I had rather stay here till day-light, and strive to nap it a little upon the softest chair I can find. (Gropes about and finds the chair on which Molkus sleeps.) So, so! Now we will try if an old sportsman can sleep without rocking after a wild-goose chace. (Sits.)

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Oh, the night-mare! The night-mare presses me!

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Thunder and lightning! What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (Clasping him in his arms.) I have him, I have him!

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Satan avaunt! Let me loose!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: The robber is caught!

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Saints and angels!—Our father—forgive our sins!—

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Light! Light here!

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Thou art the Prince of Darkness!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Where is the young lady?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Paws off, Satan!
sp.stage: Enter FREDERICK as a waiter, with a hump-back, a plaister over one of his eyes, and a light in his hand.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What's the m-m-matter here?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Ah! Molkus, is it you?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Ah! your honor, is it you? I thought it was the thief.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: And I thought it was the devil.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Why did you sit on my lap?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: I shall choose for the future rather to lay in Abraham's bosom, than to sit in your lap. My limbs tremble yet. I shall always think of the devil when I see you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What's the m-m-matter?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Ha! Who are you?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The master engaged me b-b-b-but last evening, and if such things go on in the ho-ho-house, the d-d-devil may take it for me. What do you want s-s-s-so late at night?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I ran after a young lady—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: L-l-limp you m-m-mean.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Dam'me we might better chace a hare without dogs.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: S-s-suppose I know where she is?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: B-b-but you must not b-b-betray me.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Honor, honor.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Let's hear.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The young p-p-people are st-st-still in the house.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Where, where, my good fellow?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That room—

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Is the dining-room.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Ah ha!—Well?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: They are—they—they—are not there.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Go on, go on. Where are they?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: There is the wardrobe.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Aye!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: They, they, they are n-n-not there either.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Gun-powder and flints! You booby! do you think we want to know where they are not?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: P-p-pep-patience, patience. Where they are not, they may come.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: So, so!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I overheard a whispering, and the young ge-ge-gentleman proposed hiding the lady in the wardrobe.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: An excellent place for an ambuscade!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Bu-bu-but she said, "no, it's t-t-too dark."

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Where did she choose?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The di-di-dining-room.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Oh ho! then I have her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Bu-bu-but the young ge-ge-gentleman insisted on the wardrobe.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: There then will I stand centinel.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Bu-bu-but the young lady insisted on the di-di-dining-room. "N-n-n-no," said he. "Y-y-y-yes," said she. "N-n-no." "Y-yes." "No." "Yes." "No." "Yes."—

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Thunder and lightning! How did it end?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Why thus. Now m-m-mark what I say. If you b-b-b-both go to the wardrobe and she does n-n-not come there—

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Why we shall have our trouble for our pains.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Pe-pe-perfectly right. Bu-bu-but if you b-b-both go into the dining room, and the young lady should go into the wardrobe?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Then shall we both look like fools in the morning, for having been fools all night.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Pe-pe-pe-perfectly right—bu-bu-but if one hides here and t-t-t'other there, she cannot escape you.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Bravo! bravo! Dam'me I have her already!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ke-ke-keep her fast.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Never fear me!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I take possession of the dining-room.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Do so; and if I hear that you have started the game, I'll come and join in the pursuit, or be in at the death.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: The plan of operation is complete. The allied army draws a cordon. (Limps off into dining-room.)

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Now for the wardrobe. Give me the light.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: B-b-by no means. Will she come in if she sees a light?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: True. But its damn'd dark. I hope there are no more lame devils in the house. (Goes into wardrobe.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
You may chance to meet with a little devil there, Mr. Marksman, who would prove good game if you could bring her down. (Looks at his watch.) Three o'clock. Glide, glide away! ye
leaden footed hours! Until the blessed minute comes when I shall seize my prize; and then go as ye will, or quick or dull, I dance my time out with my lovely partner, to the tune of "Merrily through the World."
sp.stage: Enter MADAME VON BRUMBACH from No. 3.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: O dear! What a terrible night! Will it never be day? Blessed be the Author of light, here's a candle! My good friend, what is the matter with this house?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (Quits the stammering and assumes a gruff short manner.) House? Good enough. Better than people

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: I have heard such a continual noise—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Cats.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: No, no!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Rats.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Besides, I have seen a horrible apparition.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Been looking in the glass.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Have you heard any thing of my daughter?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Why—yes.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: What my good fellow?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That she has run away.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: I know that already.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Who said you did not? I met her and her lover on the stairs.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: And you did not stop them!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Am I to stop all I meet on the stairs?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: But did you not see?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What did I see? A young lady with a young gentleman—such things are not strange at an inn.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: But whither went they?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: To tell you the truth, they are in the house yet.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: My good fellow, I will reward you well if you will put me in the way of finding them.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I will do it—talk of reward afterwards. First, step into the dining-room there.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: There you will find, on the left hand, a door; which leads to a long passage; where there is a lamp burning.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Go on.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: No: it is you must go on, quite to the end of the passage; where you will come to a narrow staircase.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Well? There I go up?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: No. There you go down:—and at the bottom you will find—

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Yourself in the stable-yard.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: What under Heaven am I to do there?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What you please.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Booby! But where is my daughter?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Cross the yard, until the cow-stable is on your left hand.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Fellow! I am not seeking a calf.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And straight before you, you will see the wash-house.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Thank you, good lad! she is there!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Heaven forbid!—but—next to the wash-house—

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Well? Next to the wash-house.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Is the calendering-room.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: And there she has hid herself?—Ha?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Perhaps so.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: So, so! I will just throw my cloak over my shoulders, and then.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: So, now let the old woman go on a wildgoose chace—through mud and mire. I have provided for all my friends, and let them play the rest of the game as chance shall direct. (Puts the light on the table, and exit.)

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: So!—What, is he gone? Never mind, I shall find her. Dining-room—long passage—stairs—stable-yard—cow-stable—wash-house—calendering-room. That's right. Shall I take the light or leave it? It is dark in the dining-room, but there is a lamp burning in the passage. I had better steal upon them in the dark and surprize them, as Peter the great did the conspirators.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (After a pause.) I have her! I have her!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Help! Murder! Help!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Your mama will help you! Come along! Come, miss!
sp.stage: Enter MOLKUS, from the dining-room, with the old woman in his arms. He crying out,

sp.p: I have her! I have her!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Help! Murder! (Perceiving him) Molkus!—What are you about? What are you doing?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (Stares at her, and then let's her fall and stands amazed.) The devil!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Are you drunk again?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Don't know. Drunk, or asleep, or bewitched.

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: (In the wardrobe.) I have her! I have her!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Help! Help! Murder! Help!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Ah ha! He has her! If the devil don't change her into an old woman.
sp.stage: Enter PIFFLEBERG, from the wardrobe, with LISETTE in his arms. He crying out,

sp.p: I have her! I have her! (Brings her forward.)

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Mr. Piffleberg, what are you doing with my chambermaid?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: (Stares at Lisette, drops her, and then stands amazed.) On a wrong scent, dam'me!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Very pretty, indeed! What chace have you been on?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: On a wild-goose chace, it seems.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: I am petrified! Did not I send all three of you different ways in pursuit of my daughter? and here I find you all together playing at hide-and-go-seek in the dark. Pray, Mr. Piffleberg, what was you doing in the wardrobe?

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Watching the game, widow.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Fine game, truly! And you, Molkus, what were you doing in the dining-room?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: In ambuscade.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: And you, you impudent hussey?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: I, I, I, your ladyship?—I wanted to mend the blond lace in which your ladyship tore a hole at the ball.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p:
To mend blond laces in the dark—very fine! And you, Mr. Piffleberg! Are you not ashamed of yourself? Is this love? Is this friendship?
Instead of pursuing my daughter, here do I find you in a dark corner with my chambermaid!

sp.speaker: Pif.
sp.p: Thunder and lightning! The devil may take you and your daughter too! I am tired of being fooled. The moment I set a foot in your house, all hell is let loose to torment me. One damn'd fellow blinds me with hair-powder—Another calls me his father—Another impostor talks of my little Billy—And now, when I had the young lady fast, she is changed into this pest of a chambermaid! Dam'me the place is worse than a mad-house. No, widow, I'm off. I've chang'd my mind. I am poor to be sure—but rather freedom and a roasted potatoe, than to be loaded with a foolish old woman on one side and a bag of gold on the other! Yhoix! Tally ho! Yhoix! Dam'me, I'm off, crack!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Oh, miscrable woman! Every body abandons me!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Deceived by our spies.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: However, I know where Nannette is hidden. I'll punish her, however.—Molkus!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Here!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Take the light and follow me.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Through the dining-room, into the dark passage, down the narrow stairs, into the cow-yard, past the cow-stable and the wash-house into the calendering-room.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Heaven preserve us! She's mad.
sp.stage: Enter FREDERICK, in his proper dress.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (Kneeling.) Stay, my lady, and forgive the love which has caused all this confusion.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Who are you, sir?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The man who has robbed you of your daughter.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: And how dare you—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Permit me to make reparation. I am Baron Wellinghorst, the heir of an illustrious house—

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: And if you were heir to the Emperor of Abyssinia—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I love your daughter and she loves me.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: I will never forgive you, sir. I will never give my daughter to a man who began with cheating an innocent girl out of her honor, and would bring my—black hairs with sorrow to the grave!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You do me injustice. Nannette is under the protection of an venerable old man, my tutor. He shall be my witness, that your daughter has been honorably treated. (Starts up and opens Felix's door.) Come my friend and bride! help me to soften the heart of this obdurate mother!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Ah! my husband!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: By all the devils, my wife!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Is it you, Charles?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Is it you, Salome?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Are you not dead yet?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Alas, no!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: A tender scene of meeting.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Have I not advertised you in all the news-papers?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Have I not shunned you every where?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: How edifying!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Is this lady your wife?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Alas, yes!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: How touching!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Is this my father, dear mama?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Alas, yes!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: How moving!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: (Embraces.) Dear father! What unexpected joy!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Lovely girl! you help me to support the presence of your unhappy mother.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Now, then, our difficulties end! My friend, I expect my sentence from you.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Yes, Frederick, the girl is your wife. I know your heart. The wine still ferments, but the quality is good. But, Nannette, you will often be obliged to have patience with him—

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I will have patience, dear papa.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Well, Charles, you can do as you will with your daughter. As to me, I have procured a divorce.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I have not one objection. Enjoy my property, and endeavour to be happy. I shall be happy here without it. (Places himself between Frederick and Nannette.)

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Molkus!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Here!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: You wanted to marry me last evening.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I—was drunk.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Your intoxication has soon gone off—the baron's may last these four weeks.

lg.head: Felix.
lg.l: Let us think that much happiness yet rests in store;
Hope points and we press to the place:
Joy runs with quick steps and is always before—
We follow—Huzza! to the chace!

lg.head: Lisette.
lg.l: The wild-goose chace ended; again we must start!
Tallyho! then, huzza! and away!
The young hounds are coupled as never to part:
The old ones cast off—and cry nay.

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: Let us think that much happiness yet rests in store;
Hope points and we press to the place:
Joy runs with quick steps and is always before—
We follow—Huzza! to the chace!

div.head: NOTES ON THE WILD-GOOSE CHACE.
div.p: THE title of this play in the original is Der Wildsang, which is equivalent to the English phrase of The Madcap. The English reviewers gave Wild Oats as their translation of Wildsang; and I should have adopted it, had not Mr. O'Keefe preoccupied that title.
Page 9. Song.] One acknowledgment will suffice for all the songs. They are added by the translator, who must therefore be chargeable with their faults.
Page 10. We may know, &c.] Here eighteen words, including the reference, are added by the translator.
Page 11. Thus let the pupil, &c.] Fourteen words are added.
Same page. Nay, but my good, &c.] Ten words are added.

Page 12. Angel's head and swan's, &c.] Eleven words are introduced in place of the original—"I do not understand you." These may serve as specimens of the freedom with which I have translated this play. To mark every such variation would be trifling and unnecessary.
Page 22. Between the words "Because your's was so" and "But you do not know," twenty-eight words are added, and the following lines are omitted.

sp.speaker: "Fel.
sp.p: I do not say so. A man may win at dice or draw a prize in the lottery. But I pray you make not your choice until the romantic fire of youth is exhausted.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That may be a long time. I have lately see a Issland's "Old Bachelor" represented, and poor Reinhold has made such an impression on me, that I am resolved to marry over head and heels.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: You are too young.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Youth is more easily pleased.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: And more easily disgusted.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A man may be forty years choosing and not choose well.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: You do not know the object of your love. You have seen a book in English binding and do not know its contents.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Can God have given a bad book so lovely a binding?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Better an hour of reflection, than a year of repentance.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Right, dear Mr. Felix; I will prove Nannette with all the caution of a lover.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: That, indeed, is all a lover can promise.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: In the first place, I have written her this letter, in which I tell her that I adore her.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Oh! the best possible mode of gaining a true knowledge of her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: If I only knew how to convey the letter to her.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: In time we pluck roses.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But when the rose is already expanded, there is no time to be lost.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: You have called me your friend. Well, then, make use of my eyes. Love has not varied my vision by putting spectacles on my nose.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Is love a dealer in spectacles? Or do you think it is better to borrow the microscope from the hypocondriac? He that breaks a man's spectacles is entitled to little thanks for the action."

div.p: Page 29. Lisette's soliloquy is added to introduce the song and close the act, as I thought it necessary to divide the first act on account of its excessive length.
Page 30. A few introductory words became necessary, for the above reason, in beginning the second act.

Page 31. So ho! Dam'me the widow's up.] This speech is added, and it must be acknowledged that more liberty is taken with Piffleberg than with any other of the characters except the Hair-dresser: to represent a sportsman to an American audience, I thought it necessary to make use of the language of an American (or at least an English) sportsman.
Page 42. Ah ha! my lady, pardonnez, &c.] I took the liberty to make my hair-dresser a Frenchman, and in the representation have seen no reason to repent the change.
Page 48. That's all you are, &c.] Twelve lines added to introduce the song.
Page 51. Fools' caps, &c.] Six lines added.
Page 52. If I only spoke with women, &c.] Here the following is omitted:—

sp.speaker: "Lis.
sp.p: Blockhead, what do men want in the presence of women?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Every thing but the head.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: And if there were no women, my God, who would put your heads to rights?"

div.p: Page 54. You block, stock, stick, &c.] Here ten lines are added, and the following omitted:—

sp.speaker: "Lis.
sp.p: Do but hear, how that most lovely young lady coaxes you?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: And that most lovely old lady growls.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Is then all in vain?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: All.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Perhaps you are hungry. Will you have some almond-cakes?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I eat ammunition-bread.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Come down into the kitchen, and have a piece of roast-beef to eat with it.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: It is too soon.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: It grows dark already.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Do you know why?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Because it grows late.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: And do you know why you are a blockhead?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Because you are all darkness: night in your head, and midnight in your heart.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: What is to be done with the blockhead?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Thou art an honest fellow, dear Molkus.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Am I not?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: We may converse without ceremony.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Without ceremony."

div.p: Page 55. Run away?] Here there is a small addition relative to the song, and a trifling omission.
Page 60. Better and better, &c.] Here the following is omitted:—

sp.speaker: "Fred.
sp.p: How came you in this house with women? I would rather be in barracks.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: How came I with these women?—I stand centry.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: O fye! You that have guarded the general's tent—and now watch women!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Why what's to be done, comrade?—In the field we want two legs, in winter-quarters we can do with one.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (Feigning drunkenness.) Think you so?—No, brother; he that meddles with women must have two legs at least.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (Really drunk.) Two tongues you mean."

div.p: Same page. Right! Good!] Here sixteen lines are added.
Page 66. Good night, mama.] Here the following lines are omitted:—

sp.speaker: "M. B.
sp.p: Go child, and endeavor not to sleep so much. Think on the affront you have received to-day, and you will have sufficient cause for a sleepless night.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: An affront? To me?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Have you already forgot that impudent fellow and his powder-bag?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I did not know that an offer of marriage was an affront?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: He marry you?—A boy that has just left school, and a girl that has just left the doll.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Indeed, mama, he wishes to marry me.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: So!—How know you that?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I—I—suppose—

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: I suppose that you are a fool.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Marry?—What are you thinking of, miss?—He comes, sees, loves, burns—First a flame, then coals, then ashes. Woe to the girl that makes an ash-pit of her heart.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Right, Lisette! explain this chapter to her as you go to bed."

div.p: Same page. The hour of trial, &c.] I have shortened this soliloquy.
Page 98. Your daughter.] The original play concludes thus:—

sp.speaker: "M. B.
sp.p:
But if you think that I will ever be your wife again, you are very much mistaken. I have had you cited in all the newspapers, and you are divorced from me, formally, as having been guilty of what the lawyers call
a malicious desertion. The high-consistory have written twelve sheets full about it, and put a great seal under it.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I have not the least objection. Marry if you please three husbands more, and be three times more divorced. What you possess of my property you may keep, for the sake of the lovely daughter you have given me.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: We can meet in company with politeness.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: O yes.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: And I shall never mention what I have suffered for your sake.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Then, mes chers enfans, I will no longer withhold my blessing.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: God bless ye! And, with tears in my eyes, do I conjure you to take no example from your parents.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Dearest Nannette, you are mine!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Dear father!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: For the present, children, you must separate. You, Nannette, go with your mother; and you, Frederick, come with me.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I am not at all sleepy.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: To-morrow, children, to-morrow shall your wishes be crowned. Good night, madam.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.p: Good night, sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Sleep well, dear Nannette.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Sleep well, dear Frederick.

p.hi: kiss their hands to each other.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: A curious incident.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Well, Molkus, you wished yesterday evening to marry me.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I was drunk.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: (Alone.) So! And is not the young gentleman also drunk? Aye, aye; I am afraid that in four weeks he will awake quite sober."
